title: Erickson v. Jones Street Publishers
description: Appellant served as a private guardian ad litem in a family court divorce and child custody case in Dorchester County.  Appellant sued Respondent for defamation based on statements published by Respondent in a weekly newspaper.  The trial judge dismissed Appellantâ€™s cause of action for defamation against Respondent, ruling she was a public figure for limited purposes who must prove constitutional actual malice in order to recover damages.  The trial judge also dismissed Appellantâ€™s causes of action for invasion of privacy and negligence.  The Supreme Court reversed the grant of a directed verdict to Newspaper on the issues of Appellantâ€™s status and liability for defamation.  The Supreme Court held that Appellant, as a matter of law under the facts and circumstances of this case, is a private-figure plaintiff who demonstrated Newspaper was liable for defaming her pursuant to a jury charge agreed upon by both parties.  The Supreme Court upheld the juryâ€™s findings that the published statements were false and defamatory, that Newspaper acted negligently in defaming Appellant as a private figure, and that Appellant had proven by clear and convincing evidence Newspaper acted with constitutional actual malice in publishing the statements.  Finally, the Supreme Court held Newspaper waived any objection to the jury separately considering liability and damages; therefore, the Court reinstated the juryâ€™s verdict holding Newspaper liable for the defamatory statements and remanded the case for a jury to consider the issues of actual and punitive damages.  The Supreme Court affirmed the trial judgeâ€™s rulings on remaining issues raised by Appellant.  Justice Pleicones filed a dissenting opinion.

BENCH MEMORANDUM


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Linda Erickson, Appellant,
v.
Jones Street Publishers, LLC, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Roger M. Young, Trial Judge
R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.26133
Heard January 19, 2006 - Filed April 10, 2006

AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
Russell S. Stemke, of Island Law Offices, of Isle of Palms, for Appellant.
John J. Kerr, of Buist, Moore, Smythe, & McGee, P.A., of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  Linda Erickson (Appellant) appeals the dismissal of her causes of action for defamation, invasion of privacy, and negligence against Jones Street Publishers, LLC (Newspaper).Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand for further proceedings.
FACTUAL AND PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Newspaper publishes the Charleston City Paper, a free weekly newspaper with a circulation of about 30,000.Â  Newspaper on January 19, 2000, published a front-page news story titled â€œIn A Childâ€™s Best Interest:Â  Is the guardian ad litem program giving children a voice?â€Â  In a promotional teaser in the table of contents on page three, Newspaper stated:

Protecting the Children
The Guardian Ad Litem program has come under fire recently for a series of transgressions.Â  One high profile case has a Guardian reportedly becoming romantically involved with the father of a child.Â  Critics claim volunteers with a lack of training and professional expertise have too much authority.Â  How did this happen, and what is being done to remedy the situation?Â 

In introductory paragraphs preceding the main body of the article, Newspaper stated:
Every child in the judicial system needs to have a voice.

Parents have the benefit of experience, age, and lawyers to make their case.Â  But what of a 7-year-old boy whose family is crumbling right in front of him and only sees himself to blame - who is to speak for him?
In South Carolina, they are called Guardian Ad Litems (GALs).Â  In a perfect world, they provide an objective perspective for whatâ€™s best for the child - momâ€™s house, dadâ€™s house, neither.
But what happens if their objectivity is compromised?Â  What if, while carrying out their duties, they step across the line, like sleeping with the clientâ€™s father?
Itâ€™s already happened, and the result is a public effort to abolish half of the GAL system and radically modify the other half.Â 

The article then began with a subsection titled â€œWhom to Believe?â€Â  In that first subsection, Newspaper recounted the claims of Pat Beal, a Summerville grandmother who said her daughter and two grandchildren had moved into her home to escape the daughterâ€™s physically abusive husband.Â  Pat Beal said her â€œthen six-year-old granddaughter began to complain of pain in her â€˜private area - vaginal painâ€™â€ and that â€œher granddaughter would cry out â€˜No, Daddyâ€™ in her dreams.â€Â  The family took the granddaughter to doctors to investigate â€œpossible molestations,â€ as well as to a lawyer who ultimately contacted the Department of Social Services, according to the article.
In the article, Pat Beal stated that â€œthe [guardian] assigned to the case did not do a thorough job of interviewing the family and did not even talk to the granddaughterâ€; the guardian prevented an arrangement between the parents in which the mother (Pat Bealâ€™s daughter) would get full custody of the children; the guardian â€œmanipulated the judge into barring [Pat Beal] from contacting her granddaughter without supervisionâ€; and the guardian, in the final divorce decree, â€œhad it written that she [Pat Beal] could have no contact with either of her minor grandchildren.â€Â  Pat Beal further stated in the article that she â€œbecame incensed when a second psychologist said that she had â€˜coachedâ€™ her granddaughter into alleging sexual abuse at the hands of her fatherâ€; that she and her husband had â€œspent $64,000 fighting the decree in court, and were eventually successfulâ€; and that she had joined a court reform movement begun by those who have been through â€œequally harrowing experiences with custody and abuse battles.â€
The article did not name the guardian who represented Pat Bealâ€™s granddaughter.Â  Appellant testified there were only a handful of private, non-lawyer guardians in Dorchester County at the time.Â  Two local lawyers testified they and others involved in the Dorchester County family court system were familiar with the â€œBeal case,â€ and knew Appellant was the guardian who had worked on it.Â  Furthermore, it apparently is undisputed Appellant was sufficiently identified in the article because Newspaper did not attempt to defend on that ground.[1]
Appellant alleged the teaser, introductory paragraphs, and â€œWhom to Believeâ€ subsection constituted defamation by libel.Â  Appellant alleged and testified the false and defamatory statements included the charge she failed to properly investigate the case or speak with the child she represented, that she improperly blocked and tried to prevent the mother from getting full custody of the children, that she manipulated a family court judge, that she caused a court order to be written preventing Pat Beal from having visitation with her granddaughter, and that she had a sexual relationship with the father of a child she represented. 
Appellant presented evidence that the childâ€™s â€œvaginal painâ€ was actually caused by pinworms.Â  Investigations by Appellant, DSS, physicians, and a psychologist revealed no evidence William Litchfield had sexually abused his daughter.Â  Appellant testified she concluded Pat Beal had coached her granddaughter to falsely accuse her father of sexual molestation in order to gain an advantage in the divorce and custody battle.Â  A psychologist reached the same conclusion.Â  Appellant testified the child, unprompted, said she â€œtold the doctor that my daddy did something that he really didnâ€™t.Â  My nana [Pat Beal] told me to because she wanted me to - my nana asked me to tell the doctor that my daddy hurt me and he really didnâ€™t.Â  And my mama and grandpa are afraid weâ€™re going to get in trouble.â€Â  
The family court judge in the Litchfield divorce decree ordered the parties to deny access or visitation of Pat Beal with the grandchildren until she â€œhas completed a course of counseling which addresses the issues of coaching and interfering with the relationship of these parents and children.â€Â Â  The order, the result of a settlement between the parties, was not appealed and Pat Bealâ€™s visitation rights were restored after she completed the required counseling.
Appellant exemplified something of a Horatio Alger tale.Â  She testified she had a somewhat troubled childhood and adolescence, growing up in New York with an alcoholic father.Â  She left home, dropped out of school at the age of sixteen, and had a failed relationship with a heroin addict.Â  She later met and married and the couple had two children, moving to Charleston after her husband joined the Air Force.Â  Appellantâ€™s husband was killed in a car wreck when she was twenty-five years old.Â  Appellant passed tests of General Educational Development, obtaining her â€œGED.â€Â  She then went to college for eight years while working part-time jobs and taking care of her children, eventually obtaining a bachelorâ€™s degree in sociology.Â  Appellant ultimately obtained a masterâ€™s degree in counseling and, finally, realizing part of her dream, became a licensed professional counselor able to work with children and families. 
Appellant had planned to begin her own counseling business in Dorchester County, but Appellant and two lawyers testified her reputation and chance to start a counseling business were ruined by the defamatory newspaper article.Â  No lawyer needing a guardian ad litem or family counselor could take a chance on hiring such a controversial person because it would simply bring too many extraneous issues and problems into a case. 
Appellant testified she worked from her home as a guardian ad litem and counselor in divorce and other family-related cases, and she considered her role to be a private, confidential one involving very personal matters.Â  She understood that legislators, family court officials, and others at the time were publicly debating potential changes in the guardian system, but she did not speak out publicly on the topic.
Newspaper defended the case primarily on the grounds the information in the article was true and accurate, i.e., Appellant had not properly investigated the case, had reached erroneous conclusions and recommendations too summarily, and had manipulated the family court.Â  The author of the article, Bill Davis, testified he and Newspaper handled the story carefully and appropriately.Â  Davis testified he tried to contact Appellant before publishing it even though none of his notes contained her telephone number.Â  He did not try to contact attorneys involved in the Beal case.Â  Davis conceded his only source for the â€œWhom to Believeâ€ subsection was a fifteen- to thirty-minute telephone conversation with Pat Beal.Â  Davis admitted he could have obtained the Litchfieldsâ€™ publicly recorded divorce decree, which refuted or at least called some of Pat Bealâ€™s claims into question.[2]Â  In addition, Newspaper contended Appellant was a public figure or public official required to prove constitutional actual malice, which she was unable to do, in order to prevail in the lawsuit. 
The trial initially progressed in the usual manner.Â  It appears that, by the third day, Wednesday, the trial judge expressed concern about the potential length of the trial.[3]Â  Newspaper suggested the evidence initially should be limited to issues of Appellantâ€™s status and whether she had presented sufficient evidence of actual malice to submit the case to the jury.Â  The judge, in turn, suggested the parties agree to bifurcate the case between liability and damages, an idea Appellant initially resisted.Â  By Friday morning, the decision to bifurcate the case apparently had been agreed upon and was understood by the parties, as the judge directed Appellant, â€œI donâ€™t want you to put on any damage witnesses right now.Â  Weâ€™re only talking about liability.â€[4]
On Friday afternoon, the trial judge explained to the parties he would instruct the jury after Appellant rested her case on liability and the parties presented closing arguments.Â  He would then hear arguments and rule on Newspaperâ€™s directed verdict motion on whether Appellant was a private figure, public figure, or public official while the jury deliberated.Â  The judge subsequently explained to the jury that he had â€œlimited the amount of testimony that you have heard to only questions that involve the issue of liability.â€Â  The jury would be given a special verdict form after hearing closing arguments and instructions on the law.Â  Neither party objected to the procedure.Â  Newspaper did not attempt to offer any witnesses or evidence during the liability phase of the trial.
The parties and judge discussed the jury charges and special verdict form at length.Â  Both parties made closing arguments to the jury, focusing only on whether the article was false and defamatory, and whether Appellant had shown Newspaper acted negligently or with actual malice.Â  
The judge instructed the jury it was only to determine the issue of liability, not damages, and charged the jury on the elements of a defamation action.Â  The judge told the jury not to consider the statement regarding a guardian who had a sexual relationship with the father of a child she represented.Â  The judge earlier had ruled that statement did not have a defamatory meaning with regard to Appellant because the article clearly identified another guardian accused of that act.Â  Because he had not yet ruled on the issue of Appellantâ€™s status, the judge charged the jury on both private figure and negligence law, and the concepts of public figure, public official, and constitutional actual malice.Â  The judge explained the special verdict form in detail to the jury.
While the jury was out, the judge heard arguments on Newspaperâ€™s directed verdict motion that Appellant was a public figure or public official who must prove Newspaper acted with actual malice, a burden she had failed to meet.Â  The judge did not rule on the motion before the jury returned with its verdict.
The special verdict form approved by both parties posed four yes/no questions:Â  (1) whether Appellant had proven by a preponderance of the evidence that Newspaper published a statement about Appellant that was false; (2) whether Appellant had proven by a preponderance that the false statement about Appellant was defamatory; (3) whether Appellant had proven by a preponderance that Newspaperâ€™s publication of a false and defamatory statement about Appellant was negligent; and (4) whether Appellant had proven by clear and convincing evidence that Newspaper acted with actual malice in publishing a false and defamatory statement about Appellant.[5]Â  The jury answered â€œyesâ€ to all four questions.
The trial judge told jurors they would have to return the following week to consider evidence of Appellantâ€™s damages, and sent them out to discuss when they would prefer to return.Â  The judge then denied Newspaperâ€™s directed verdict motion, ruling Appellant was a private figure required to prove negligence to recover damages in her defamation action.
At this point the case took an unusual procedural turn.Â  Newspaper moved for a mistrial because the judge had told jurors they would return only to determine damages, but Newspaper had not yet presented a defense.Â  The judge agreed to correct his â€œmisstatement.â€Â  He called the jurors back in and told them that they would return to hear evidence of Appellantâ€™s damages and Newspaperâ€™s defense.Â  The questions the jury answered in the special verdict form were only â€œadvisory interrogatories.â€ 
On Monday morning, Newspaper restated its objection to the process followed.Â  Counsel stated it had â€œnever crossed my mind, of course, that you would let the case go out to the jury if there was any - if you had anything going on in your mind that I was going to put up a defense. . . . I thought you were sending a clear signal to me that I wasnâ€™t putting up a defense in this case.Â  What else could it be to send the jury out before I put up a defense?â€Â  Newspaper believed the judge planned to dismiss the case on its directed verdict motion even if the jury returned with all â€œyesâ€ answers.Â  The jury was tainted in Appellantâ€™s favor by already discussing the merits of the case and ruling on â€œadvisory interrogatories.â€ 
After much discussion, the judge instructed the jury the â€œspecial interrogatoriesâ€ it had answered â€œare not binding upon you during the remainder of the trial.â€Â  Appellant would present evidence of damages and Newspaper would present its defense.Â  The case would be submitted anew to the jury, which would not be bound by its earlier answers in the special verdict form. 
Accordingly, Appellant presented evidence of damages to her reputation, emotional distress and accompanying physical problems, and loss of the opportunity to start her own counseling business, then rested her case.Â  Newspaper renewed its directed verdict motion on Appellantâ€™s status, which was denied.
Newspaper presented its defense, recalling the reporter (who already had testified in Appellantâ€™s case), Appellant, and the psychologist mentioned by Pat Beal in the article.Â  Newspaper questioned Appellant about Karen Winner, the author of the â€œWinner reportâ€ which discussed the actions of private guardians in several family court cases.Â  Appellant testified she had separately sued Winner and several other persons for defamation.Â  Appellant testified she asked another guardian ad litem (Marilyn Lassiter, who was named and accused of wrongdoing in the same article) to attend a publicly advertised meeting and secretly tape-record it because she had been told â€œthat a group had been formed to ruin me [and] to try to put me in jail.â€Â  Appellant also had listened to audiotapes secretly made by two other friends who had attended the groupâ€™s meetings.Â  Newspaper questioned Appellant about three private letters she wrote in 1999 regarding the guardian reform controversy and questions about her education and training to two Governorâ€™s Office officials.Â  
Newspaper renewed its directed verdict motion on Appellantâ€™s status and the judge heard additional arguments.Â  Reversing his earlier decision, the judge ruled Appellant was a limited public figure who had not presented clear and convincing evidence to prove Newspaper acted with actual malice.Â  Therefore, the judge granted Newspaperâ€™s directed verdict motion.Â  The case was not resubmitted to the jury.
Newspaperâ€™s motions to dismiss Appellantâ€™s claims for negligence and invasion of privacy had been previously granted pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, after a pretrial hearing by another circuit judge. Â Appellant appealed the rulings of both judges.Â  This appeal was certified to the Court on motion of the Court of Appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b),
SCACR.  
Appellant raises numerous issues.Â  We find it necessary to discuss only three issues and we affirm the remaining issues pursuant to Rule 220(c), SCACR.
ISSUES

I.Â  Did the trial judge err in ruling that Appellant, a private guardian ad litem appointed to represent the childrenâ€™s interests in a divorce and child custody dispute, was a limited public figure who must prove constitutional actual malice in order to recover damages in a defamation action?
II.Â  Does sufficient evidence support the juryâ€™s finding of constitutional actual malice such that Appellant, if she is determined to be a private figure, is entitled to recover punitive damages from Newspaper?
III.Â  Did Newspaper agree to bifurcation of the trial on liability and damages, consequently waiving the right to object to bifurcation or its decision not to present evidence during the liability phase of the trial?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
In ruling on a motion for directed verdict, the trial court must view the evidence and the inferences which reasonably can be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the party opposing the motion.Â  The trial court must deny the motion when either the evidence yields more than one inference or its inference is in doubt.Â  Strange v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Highways & Pub. Transp., 314 S.C. 427, 429-30, 445 S.E.2d 439, 440 (1994).Â  When considering directed verdict motions, neither the trial court nor the appellate court has authority to decide credibility issues or to resolve conflicts in the testimony or evidence.Â  Creech v. S.C. Wildlife and Marine Resources Depâ€™t, 328 S.C. 24, 491 S.E.2d 571 (1997).Â  The appellate court must determine whether a verdict for a party opposing the motion would be reasonably possible under the facts as liberally construed in his favor.Â  Bultman v. Barber, 277 S.C. 5, 7, 281 S.E.2d 791, 792 (1981).Â  If the evidence is susceptible to more than one reasonable inference, the case should be submitted to the jury.Â  Quesinberry v. Rouppasong, 331 S.C. 589, 594, 503 S.E.2d 717, 720 (1998).
When ruling on a motion for summary judgment or directed verdict in a defamation action, the court must review the evidence using the same substantive evidentiary standard of proof the jury is required to use in a particular case.Â  George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 451-54, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874-75 (2001).Â  An appellate court reviews the granting of such a motion using the same standard.Â  Id.
In an action at law, on appeal of a case tried by a jury, the jurisdiction of the appellate court extends merely to the correction of errors of law, and a factual finding by the jury will not be disturbed unless a review of the record discloses that there is no evidence which reasonably supports the juryâ€™s findings.Â  Townes Assoc, Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 221 S.E.2d 773 (1976).
LAW AND ANALYSIS
I.Â  APPELLANTâ€™S STATUS AS A PUBLIC OFFICIAL, PUBLIC FIGURE, OR PRIVATE FIGURE
Appellant argues the trial judge erred in granting Newspaperâ€™s directed verdict motion that Appellant, a private guardian ad litem appointed to represent the childrenâ€™s interests in a divorce and child custody dispute, was a limited public figure who must prove constitutional actual malice in order to recover damages.Â  Prior to publication of the article, Appellant was not famous, had no special access to the media, never sought the publicâ€™s attention, did not thrust herself voluntarily into a public controversy, and did not assume any special prominence in the resolution of an issue of public concern.Â  While the debate about potential reform of the guardian system was a public controversy, Appellant contends she was a private figure who must prove by a preponderance of the evidence that Newspaper acted negligently in publishing false and defamatory statements about her in order to recover damages.Â  We agree in part.
The tort of defamation allows a plaintiff to recover for injury to his or her reputation as the result of the defendantâ€™s communications to others of a false message about the plaintiff.Â  Holtzscheiter v. II.Â  CONSTITUTIONAL ACTUAL MALICE
The jury in its special verdict form determined Appellant had proven by clear and convincing evidence Newspaper acted with constitutional actual malice, i.e., Newspaper published the statement with knowledge it was false or with reckless disregard of whether it was false or not.Â  This finding is relevant in Appellantâ€™s case because, as a private figure, she is entitled to recover punitive damages from a media defendant only if she proves actual malice.Â  See Gertz, 418 U.S. at 346-50, 94 S.Ct. at 3010-12, 41 L.Ed.2d at 809-11; Holtzscheiter II, 332 S.C. at 512, 506 S.E.2d at 503.Â  Newspaper argues the record does not support a finding of actual malice.Â  We disagree.
Whether evidence is sufficient to support a juryâ€™s finding of constitutional actual malice in a defamation action is a question of law.Â  The trial court must make such a determination before submitting the issue to a jury.Â  When the jury makes such a finding, the appellate court must independently examine the record to determine whether the evidence sufficiently supports a finding of actual malice.Â  Elder v. Gaffney Ledger, 341 S.C. 108, 113, 533 S.E.2d 899, 901-02 (2000) (citing Harte-Hanks Commun., Inc. v. Connaughton, 491 U.S. 657, 685-86, 109 S.Ct. 2678, 2694-95, 105 L.Ed.2d 562, 587 (1989).Â  This review is necessary due to the â€œunique character of the interest protected by the actual malice standard.Â  Our profound national commitment to the free exchange of ideas, as enshrined in the First Amendment, demands that the law of libel carve out an area of â€˜breathing spaceâ€™ so that protected speech is not discouraged.â€Â  Harte-Hanks Commun., 491 U.S. at 686, 109 S.Ct. at 2695, 105 L.Ed.2d at 587; accord George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 456-57, 548 S.E.2d 868, 876 (2001).
As we explained in Elder,

Elder, 341 S.C. at 114, 533 S.E.2d at 902 (citations, quotes, and emphasis omitted).Â  â€œA subjective awareness of probable falsity can be shown if there are obvious reasons to doubt the veracity of the informant or accuracy of his report.â€Â  Anderson v. Augusta Chronicle, 365 S.C. 589, 596, 619 S.E.2d 428, 432 (2005) (citing Harte-Hanks Commun., 491 U.S. at 688, 109 S.Ct. at 2696, 105 L.Ed.2d at 589).Â  â€œThe right of a free press is not absolute in a society that demands social responsibility and personal integrity. . . . Â In the interests of justice, we will not allow a publication to go so unchecked as to promote the tyrannical imposition of false and misleading information - the very concern our forefathers sought to eliminate in demanding the press be free.â€Â  Anderson , 365 S.C. at 599-600, 619 S.E.2d at 433 (Burnett, J., concurring).
In the present case, Newspaper published allegations in a front-page story about a private figure which, on their face, appear potentially devastating to the reputation of a private guardian ad litem.Â  Evidence supporting the juryâ€™s finding of actual malice includes (1) the fact that the portion of the article pertaining to Appellant was based solely on a fifteen- to thirty-minute telephone conversation with Pat Beal, an admittedly â€œincensedâ€ person; (2) the fact Newspaper purportedly failed to even try to contact Appellant to discuss the matter with her; (3) the fact Newspaper failed to contact attorneys or others involved in the Litchfield case; and (4) the fact Newspaper failed to even try to obtain the publicly recorded divorce decree in the Litchfield case, a reading of which would have called into question or refuted Pat Bealâ€™s allegations.Â  This evidence does not indicate merely a failure to investigate which, standing alone, would be insufficient to uphold a finding of actual malice.Â  This evidence constitutes a failure to investigate before publishing an article when there were obvious reasons to doubt the veracity of Pat Beal or the accuracy of her report.Â  Thus, the evidence indicates Newspaperâ€™s subjective awareness of probable falsity of the report and is sufficient to support the juryâ€™s finding of actual malice.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the juryâ€™s finding of actual malice and remand this case for a jury to consider the issue of punitive damages.
III.Â  NEWSPAPERâ€™S WAIVER OF OBJECTION TO BIFURCATIONÂ Â Â  
A jury has not yet determined whether Appellant is owed any money damages in this matter.Â  In reversing the trial judgeâ€™s grant of a directed verdict to Newspaper on the issues of Appellantâ€™s status and liability, and remanding for a jury to determine whether to award damages, we must necessarily address whether the juryâ€™s verdict on liability must stand or whether this case should be remanded for a new trial absolute.
Appellant asserts the trial judge plainly bifurcated the case on liability and damages.Â  After doing so, the judge was without authority to subsequently reopen the liability issue or disturb the juryâ€™s verdict on liability by treating it as a response to â€œadvisory interrogatoriesâ€ which could be ignored in reaching a new verdict addressing both liability and damages.Â  Newspaper made a â€œcalculated tactical decisionâ€ in declining to present a defense during the liability phase.Â  Appellant argues Newspaper acquiesced to the procedure followed because Newspaper anticipated tired jurors would quickly return a defense verdict.[11]
Newspaper, at trial, in its brief, and at oral argument before us freely admitted it fully expected the judge to rule in Newspaperâ€™s favor on the directed verdict motion regardless of any verdict returned by the jury.Â  In its brief, Newspaper states it â€œconsented to the procedure advocated by the trial judge because there was more than enough evidence in the record at the time to ensure a directed verdict.Â  By sending the jury out to deliberate, counsel assumed, incorrectly, that the trial judge did not want [jurors] to spend a week of their lives in the jury box for nothing.Â  The belief that the trial judge would not send a jury out to deliberate before hearing all the evidence led the [Newspaperâ€™s] attorney to assume he would not be offering a defense to a deliberating jury.Â  A granting of [Newspaperâ€™s] motion for directed verdict was thus perfunctory.â€Â  (Emphasis in original.)Â  Newspaper asserts the procedure followed, while unusual, was acceptable and â€œ[t]here was no harm suffered by Appellant due to the procedure.â€
The resolution of factual issues may be submitted to an advisory jury in a case arising in equity.Â  See Momeier v. McAlister, Inc., 190 S.C. 529, 538-39, 3 S.E.2d 606, 610 (1939) (judge in equity case has the right and power to refer issues to a jury for the enlightenment of his conscience and is not bound to accept juryâ€™s findings or verdict); First State Sav. and Loan Assn. v. Nodine, 291 S.C. 445, 448, 354 S.E.2d 51, 52-53 (Ct. App. 1987) (same); Neal v. Darby, 282 S.C. 277, 283, 318 S.E.2d 18, 22 (Ct. App. 1984) (same); Rule 39(c), SCRCP (providing for advisory jury in all actions not triable of right by a jury); Rule 52(a), SCRCP (requiring court to state findings of fact and conclusions of law in case tried with advisory jury).
The instant case in which Appellant seeks money damages for defamation arises in law, not in equity.Â  See Cooper v. Poston, 326 S.C. 46, 483 S.E.2d 750 (1997) (parties in legal action for recovery of money damages are constitutionally entitled to a jury trial).Â  It is improper in a law case to submit factual issues to a jury in the form of non-binding â€œadvisory interrogatories.â€Â  A juryâ€™s resolution of factual issues in a law case is binding on trial and appellate courts.Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 85, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  Moreover, it is improper in any case - arising in either law or equity - to ask jurors to resolve factual issues and then, after hearing additional evidence, reconsider the same issues and render another verdict.Â  In this case, the deliberations and decision of the jury would have been irrevocably tainted if, after it had discussed the case and rendered a verdict in favor of Appellant on the issue of liability, it was asked to ignore the earlier verdict and reconsider the issue of liability.Â  Therefore, the trial judge erred to the extent he attempted, at Newspaperâ€™s insistence, to transform the juryâ€™s verdict on liability into â€œadvisory interrogatoriesâ€ which could be reconsidered in a subsequent verdict addressing both liability and damages.Â  We do not condone this unusual trial procedure.
The trial judge plainly bifurcated the case on liability and damages with the consent of both parties.Â  That is the procedure the parties discussed and the ruling the judge made, as shown by facts discussed above.Â  The parties participated in the preparation of a special verdict form on liability, made closing arguments on liability, the judge instructed the jury and stated it was to consider only the liability issue and not damages, and the issues of liability were presented to the jury in the special verdict form.Â  Contrary to Newspaperâ€™s argument, the record contains no indication the trial judge initially submitted the case to jurors simply to allow them to participate fruitlessly in the trial process because they had spent more than a week listening to testimony and evidence.
Further, Newspaper chose, whether for tactical or other reasons, to acquiesce to bifurcation and not present a defense during the liability phase.Â  Newspaper waived any objection it may have to bifurcation of the case, as well as its decision not to present evidence during the liability phase.Â  See e.g. Charleston Lumber Co., 338 S.C. at 175, 525 S.E.2d at 871 (unappealed ruling, right or wrong, is the law of the case and requires affirmance).Â  It would be patently inappropriate and unfair to Appellant, as well as a violation of well-established preservation of error principles and notions of judicial economy, to give Newspaper a second chance under these circumstances to present its evidence regarding liability to a different jury in a new trial absolute.Â  See e.g. Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 422, 526 S.E.2d 716, 724 (2000) (preservation of error rules â€œprevent[] a party from keeping an ace card up his sleeve - intentionally or by chance - in the hope that an appellate court will accept that ace card and, via a reversal, give him another opportunity to prove his caseâ€); Shearer, 240 S.C. at 484, 126 S.E.2d at 520 (party may not complain on appeal of error or object to trial procedure which his own conduct has induced). 
In sum, we conclude the case was bifurcated on liability and damages, and Newspaper waived any objection it may have to bifurcation and its decision not to present evidence during the liability phase.Â  Therefore, we reinstate the juryâ€™s liability verdict and remand this case for a jury to consider the issues of actual and punitive damages.
IV.Â  REMAINING ISSUES
First, Appellant contends the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment to Newspaper on her cause of action for invasion of privacy pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP.Â  We affirm the dismissal of that action because we find it unnecessary to address it given our disposition of other issues raised in this appeal.Â  See Whiteside v. Cherokee County School Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993) (appellate court need not address remaining issues when resolution of prior issue is dispositive); Rule 220(c), SCACR (appellate court may affirm for any reason appearing in the record).
In doing so, however, we do not intend to unwittingly limit evidence Appellant may present about her damages.Â  The types of damages awarded in defamation and invasion of privacy actions often overlap.Â  Viewed in general terms and not necessarily in the context of this case, a person may suffer emotional distress for two simultaneous reasons - the ruining of his reputation by a libelous statement and the wrongful publicizing of a private matter.Â  See Snakenberg v. Hartford Cas. Ins. Co., 299 S.C. 164, 170-71, 383 S.E.2d 2, 5-6 (Ct. App. 1989) (identifying three causes of action which may arise under rubric of invasion of privacy:Â  wrongful appropriation of personality, wrongful publicizing of private affairs, and wrongful intrusion into private affairs); Brown v. Pearson, 326 S.C. 409, 422, 483 S.E.2d 477, 484 (Ct. App. 1997) (noting no South Carolina case has recognized a â€œfalse lightâ€ invasion of privacy claim).Â  Similarly, a private figure who is defamed may feel that the veil of relative privacy most people enjoy has been shredded, wrongfully and unfairly exposing his actions, work, or life to the world.Â  A private figure such as Appellant who proves she has been defamed is not barred from asserting damages rooted in the loss of her privacy simply because they are raised in a defamation action and not in an invasion of privacy action.Â  
Second, Appellant contends the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment to Newspaper on her cause of action for negligence pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP.Â  We affirm the ruling of the circuit court.Â  A claim that a statement constitutes libel or slander must be brought in a defamation cause of action, which is grounded in and affected by both common and constitutional law.Â  Again, in affirming the dismissal of the negligence action, we do not intend to limit evidence Appellant may present about her damages.Â  This defamation case was brought, argued, charged, and resolved in part on a negligence theory; therefore, the types of damages generally available to a plaintiff who proves negligence are available to Appellant.
Third, Appellant contends the trial judge erred in granting a partial directed verdict on her allegation that the article may be read to say that Appellant was the guardian who had an illicit relationship with the father of the child she had been appointed to represent, a child who allegedly had been sexually molested by the father.Â  Appellant asserts a reader may reasonably link the promotional teaser in the table of contents and introductory paragraph - both of which mentioned a guardian who had slept with a represented childâ€™s father - to Appellant.Â  Appellant further notes two lawyers testified they understood the article to state she had slept with a represented childâ€™s father.Â  We disagree with Appellant and affirm this ruling of the trial judge.
â€œ[T]he intent and meaning of an alleged defamatory statement must be gathered not only from the words singled out as libelous, but from the context; all of the parts of the publication must be considered in order to ascertain the true meaning, and words are not to be given a meaning other than that which the context would show them to have.â€Â  Boone v. Sunbelt Newspapers, Inc., 347 S.C. 571, 582, 556 S.E.2d 732, 738 (Ct. App. 2001) (quoting Jones v. Garner, 250 S.C. 479, 485, 158 S.E.2d 909, 912 (1968)).
The article states one guardian had been accused of sleeping with the father of a child she represented, and plainly identifies that guardian. Â We agree with the trial judge that a reading of the article as a whole would make clear to a reasonable reader the identity of the guardian linked to this allegation of wrongdoing.Â  Consequently, Appellant may not recover damages for this statement because the trial judge properly ruled it did not refer to her and the juryâ€™s liability verdict was not based on it.
We affirm the trial judgeâ€™s rulings on remaining issues raised by Appellant because it is unnecessary to address them given our disposition of this appeal.Â  See Whiteside, 311 S.C. at 340, 428 S.E.2d at 889; Rule 220(c), SCACR.
CONCLUSION
We reverse the trial judgeâ€™s grant of a directed verdict to Newspaper on the issues of Appellantâ€™s status and liability for defamation.Â  Appellant, as a matter of law under the facts and circumstances of this case, is a private-figure plaintiff who demonstrated Newspaper was liable for defaming her pursuant to a jury charge agreed upon by both parties.Â  The jury determined by a preponderance of the evidence that the published statements were false and defamatory, and that Newspaper acted negligently in defaming Appellant as a private figure. Â These factual findings are supported by evidence in the record and will not be disturbed on appeal. Â The jury further determined Appellant had proven by clear and convincing evidence Newspaper acted with constitutional actual malice in publishing the statements.Â  Our independent examination of the record reveals evidence which sufficiently supports the juryâ€™s finding of actual malice. 
The case was bifurcated on liability and damages with the consent of both parties.Â  Newspaper waived any objection it may have to bifurcation.Â  Therefore, we reinstate the juryâ€™s verdict holding Newspaper liable for the defamatory statements.Â  We remand this case for a jury to consider the issues of actual and punitive damages to Appellant.Â  The trial judgeâ€™s rulings on remaining issues raised by Appellant are affirmed.
 AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, J., and Acting Justice Clyde N. Davis, Jr., concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., concurring in part, dissenting in part in a separate opinion.
JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I concur in part and dissent in part.Â  I agree with the majority opinion that Appellant was a private figure and that the directed verdict on the defamation action should be reversed.[12]Â  I respectfully dissent from the majority opinionâ€™s decision to â€œreinstate the juryâ€™s verdict holding Newspaper liable for defamatory statements.â€Â  In my opinion, there is no jury verdict to reinstate, and I would therefore remand the case for a new trial on liability and damages.Â  
As the majority observes, â€œthe record contains no indication the trial judge initially submitted the case to jurorsâ€ for the purpose of rendering an advisory verdict.Â  Further, the majority opinion correctly observes that Newspaper did not object to the trial judgeâ€™s submission of the case to the jury despite Newspaperâ€™s having not yet presented a defense on liability.Â  Because of this failure, Newspaper would ordinarily be bound by the juryâ€™s factual determinations.Â  Appellant herself, however, never objected to the trial courtâ€™s subsequent ruling that the juryâ€™s factual determinations were merely advisory.Â  The court and the parties proceeded under the ruling that the jury had not yet delivered a verdict on liability, and the court directed a verdict in favor of Newspaper before the case was properly submitted to the jury.Â  Finding no jury verdict to â€œreinstate,â€ and finding the direction of a verdict improper, I would remand the case for a new trial on liability and damages.

[1]Â  The parties and witnesses often referred to â€œthe Beal case,â€ as it was commonly known.Â  The divorce case was William Litchfield v. Carla Litchfield, who were divorced by an order filed April 13, 1998, about two years before the article was published.Â Â  
[2]Â  Davis repeatedly stated the article accurately and truthfully reported Pat Bealâ€™s comments and opinions on the guardian ad litem system and her daughterâ€™s custody battle.Â  Newspaper repeats this same comment in its brief, stating it planned at trial to â€œdemonstrate conclusively that there were four statements and the [Newspaperâ€™s] source honestly thought them to be true.â€Â  This position distorts the concept that truth is a defense to defamation when, as occurred in this case, it is undisputed that certain statements were uttered and later published accurately in written form.Â  A defendant or publisher asserting truth as a defense must prove that the statement or purported fact is true, not that the person quoted actually made the statement.Â  E.g. Curtis Pub. Co. v. Butts, 388 U.S. 130, 151 (1967) (truth is an absolute defense in almost all libel and slander cases); Boone v. Sunbelt Newspapers, Inc., 347 S.C. 571, 580, 556 S.E.2d 732, 737 (Ct. App. 2001) (publisher may avoid liability in any type of defamation case by proving the statement is true).
[3] The trial lasted eight days, from March 22-30, 2004.Â  Appellant was on the witness stand from Monday, March 22, through Thursday morning, March 25. 
[4]Â  Newspaper states that the trial judge communicated his decision regarding bifurcation of the trial in off-the-record discussions on Wednesday evening and Thursday morning. 
[5]Â  The form instructed the jury to answer Question 2 only if the answer to Question 1 was â€œyes,â€ and to answer Questions 3 and 4 only if it answered â€œyesâ€ to the first two questions.Â  The form further instructed the jury that Question 3 applied only if the Court found Appellant was a private figure, and Question 4 applied only if the Court found Appellant was a public figure or public official.
[6]Â  General damages include injury to reputation, mental suffering, hurt feelings, emotional distress, and similar types of injuries which are not capable of definite money valuation.Â  Special damages are tangible losses or injuries to the plaintiffâ€™s property, business, occupation, or profession in which it is possible to identify a specific amount of money as damages.Â  Holtzscheiter II, 332 S.C. at 510 n.4, 506 S.E.2d at 502 n.4.
[7]Â  Under the common law, slander is actionable per se only when it charges the plaintiff with one of five types of acts or characteristics:Â  (1) commission of a crime of moral turpitude; (2) contraction of a loathsome disease; (3) adultery; (4) unchastity; or (5) unfitness in oneâ€™s business or profession.Â  Holtzscheiter II, 332 S.C. at 511 n.5, 506 S.E.2d at 502 n.5.
[8]Â  The United States Supreme Court has explained that deciding whether a particular topic is a matter of public controversy or concern, while important in the analysis of a defamation action, is of lesser import than determining a plaintiffâ€™s status.Â  â€œWhatever their general validity, use of such subject-matter classifications to determine the extent of constitutional protection afforded defamatory falsehoods may too often result in an improper balance between the competing interests in this area. Â It was our recognition and rejection of this weakness in the Rosenbloom test which led us in Gertz to eschew a subject-matter test for one focusing upon the character of the defamation plaintiff.â€Â  Time, 424 U.S. at 454-56, 95 S. Ct. at 965-66, 47 L.Ed.2d at 164 (citing Rosenbloom v. Metromedia, 403 U.S. 29, 91 S. Ct. 1811, 29 L.Ed.2d 296 (1971)).
[9]Â  The ruling could be made before trial pursuant to a pretrial motion when facts pertaining to a plaintiffâ€™s status are either stipulated or sufficiently known, or made during trial after pertinent facts are sufficiently established.Â  An earlier ruling may better focus the attention of the court and parties on pertinent issues and evidence.
[10]Â  This Court upheld a jury verdict in favor of a private-figure plaintiff against a media defendant that apparently was grounded in negligence, although the issue was not addressed.Â  Jones v. Sun Publishing Co., 278 S.C. 12, 292 S.E.2d 23 (1982).Â  We have found no other South Carolina authority addressing the issue of using a negligence standard in private-figure defamation cases. 
[11]Â  Appellant needlessly muddles this issue by stating the jury was â€œdischarged,â€ which caused the circuit court to lose subject matter jurisdiction.Â  The jury was not discharged Friday evening.Â  It was sent home for the weekend and told to return Monday.Â  There is no issue of subject matter jurisdiction.
[12] 
I agree with the majority opinion that the partial directed verdict regarding the language in the article about a guardianâ€™s relationship with a man should be affirmed.Â  I additionally agree with all other holdings in section IV of the majority opinion.

title: Anthony Law v. SCDOC
description: The Court affirmed as modified the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment for Respondent on Appellantsâ€™ malicious prosecution claims, directed verdict for Respondent on Appellantsâ€™ wrongful termination claims, and judgment notwithstanding the verdict for Respondent on Appellantsâ€™ false imprisonment claims.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Anthony Law, Vondeste G. Mole, Mark Holmes, Arthur A. Vaughan, Harry Jenkins, and Kenneth Green,
Appellants,
v.
South Carolina Department of Corrections, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Allendale County
Â Daniel F.Â  Pieper, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26134 Â Â Â 
Heard January 18, 2006 - Filed April 10, 2006

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
Charles E. Johnson, of Columbia, for Appellants.
Marvin C. Jones and R. Clenten Campbell, both of Bogoslow, Jones, Stephens & Duffie, PA, of Walterboro, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  Anthony Law, Vondeste Mole, Mark Holmes, Arthur Vaughan, Harry Jenkins, and Kenneth Green (Appellants) appeal the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment for South Carolina Department of Corrections (Respondent) on their malicious prosecution claims, the trial courtâ€™s grant of directed verdict for Respondent on their wrongful termination claims, and the trial courtâ€™s grant of judgment notwithstanding the verdict (JNOV) for Respondent on their false imprisonment claims.Â  We affirm as modified.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In early 1999, Willie Harrison, an inmate at the Allendale Correctional Institution (Institution), contacted Geraldine Miro, the Institutionâ€™s warden.Â  Harrison alleged Appellants, who were correctional officers at Institution, were trafficking drugs into and within the Institution.Â  He further alleged Appellants gave him drugs to sell to other inmates and he, in return, gave them money from those drug transactions.Â  Harrison also claimed Appellants would shake him down to collect the monetary proceeds from the drug sales.Â  Miro contacted Al Waters, Director of Internal Affairs for Respondent, who set up an internal investigation and assigned Investigators Melissa Nettles and Joseph Baker to the case. 
As part of the internal investigation, Nettles contacted the Greenville County Sheriffâ€™s Department to verify Harrisonâ€™s credibility, and they advised her that Harrison had provided them with reliable information on prior occasions.Â  Nettles and Baker interviewed at least four inmates prior to March 25, 1999, who corroborated Harrisonâ€™s allegations.Â  At trial, Nettles gave the following examples of information corroborated prior to March 25: inmate Larry David asserted Holmes was his drug supplier; inmate Eckerin Frazier said he received marijuana from Holmes and had paid Holmes over $4,700 from June 1998 to January 1999; Frazier also claimed Law, Holmes, Jenkins, and Green worked together to sell drugs in the Institution; and inmate Terry Fuller said he observed Law and Holmes give drugs to Harrison.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Nettles and Baker interviewed at least thirty-eight inmates at the Institution from March 15, 1999 to April 20, 1999, with at least twenty inmates corroborating Harrisonâ€™s allegations.Â  Nettles and Baker also searched bank records for Mole and Vaughan which showed large cash deposits and wire transfers during the latter part of 1998 and the early part of 1999.
Nettles testified Harrison told her that Vaughan had purchased a mobile home with the money received from Harrison through the drug deals.Â  Harrison gave Nettles a specific description of the mobile home, including where Vaughan purchased it and the purchase price.Â  Nettles confirmed these two details.Â  Harrison also picked Vaughanâ€™s mobile home from a photo lineup.
Waters testified the senior staff met and decided Nettles and Baker would apply for arrest warrants for Appellants.Â  Nettles testified she assisted in preparing the affidavits and she and Baker gave sworn, oral testimony to support the warrants.Â  She told the magistrate that Harrisonâ€™s allegations had been corroborated and gave the magistrate the same kind of examples of corroboration that she gave during trial. 
On March 25, 1999, Law, Mole, Holmes, Jenkins, and Vaughan were charged with conspiracy to traffic cocaine greater than 100 grams.Â  Law, Holmes, Jenkins, and Vaughan were arrested while at work and were held at the Institution from approximately 6:30 p.m. on March 25 until 2:00 a.m. on March 26, at which time they were transported to the county jail.Â  Mole was also arrested by the Dorchester County Police Department on March 25 while traveling through Dorchester County.
Upon arrest, Holmes admitted he had received $200 from Harrison in exchange for one ounce of marijuana but denied giving Harrison the marijuana.Â  Upon arrest, Law admitted receiving money from Harrison and accused Holmes, Vaughan, Jenkins, and Green of running a drug ring within the Institution.Â  On March 26, 1999, Law and Holmes were charged with misprision of a felony, common law, and acceptance of rebates or extra compensation, and Mole was charged with misprision of a felony, common law. 
Green was arrested at work on April 15, 1999 and detained for approximately six to seven hours.Â  He was charged with conspiracy to traffic crack cocaine, greater than 10 grams but less than 28 grams.Â  
Based on the charges and the ongoing investigation, Respondent administratively suspended Appellants effective on the date of their arrests.Â  A review meeting before the warden was scheduled for each Appellant.Â  Respondent sent letters of termination to several Appellants but later rescinded the terminations.Â  
Jenkins and Law voluntarily resigned on March 29, 1999; Green and Holmes voluntarily resigned on April 30, 1999, and May 21, 1999, respectively.Â  None of the Appellants who voluntarily resigned filed a grievance with Respondent, but Green did request a review hearing.Â  Mole was terminated on May 7, 1999, and Vaughan was terminated on May 20, 1999.Â  After his termination, Mole filed a grievance report with Respondent and an investigative review was conducted by Respondentâ€™s General Counselâ€™s Office.Â  The Deputy Director of Operations upheld Moleâ€™s termination and the Director of Respondent subsequently upheld the termination.Â  Also after his termination, Vaughan filed a grievance.
The indictments against Appellants were nolle prossed because â€œ[t]he arresting agency has chosen to pursue these charges in federal court.â€Â  Nettles and Baker testified after making the arrests they consulted with Solicitor Randolph Murdaugh, who decided to turn the cases over to the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI). Nettles and Baker continued to help the FBI with the investigation until the end of their employment with Respondent.
After filing verified claims with Respondent, Appellants individually sued Respondent on February 21, 2001.Â  Each Appellant sued under the South Carolina Tort Claims Act[1] for: (1) civil conspiracy, (2) defamation, (3) false imprisonment, (4) malicious prosecution, and (5) wrongful discharge.Â  Respondent simultaneously filed motions to dismiss and Answers on April 16, 2001.
Appellantsâ€™ cases were consolidated for trial.Â  Prior to trial, Appellantsâ€™ causes of actions for defamation and civil conspiracy were dismissed by Appellantsâ€™ consent.Â  Respondent also moved for summary judgment on all causes of action.Â  The trial judge granted summary judgment on the malicious prosecution claims only.Â  
At the close of Appellantsâ€™ cases, the trial judge granted a directed verdict for Respondent on the wrongful termination claims.Â  The jury returned a verdict for Appellants on their false imprisonment claims, awarding $25,000 to each Appellant.Â  The trial judge granted Respondentâ€™s motion for JNOV.Â  This appeal follows, and this Court certified the case for review from the Court of Appeals, pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.
ISSUES

  
    
      
        I.  
         Did the trial court err in granting Respondentâ€™s motion for summary judgment on the malicious prosecution claims?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        II. 
         Did the trial court err in granting Respondentâ€™s motion for directed verdict on the wrongful termination claims?Â 
      
      
        
         
      
      
        III. 
         Did the trial court err in granting Respondentâ€™s motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict on the false imprisonment claims?Â 
      
    
  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, the appellate court applies the same standard that governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Under Rule 56, SCRCP, a party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law if the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact.  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist for summary judgment purposes, the evidence and all the inferences which can be reasonably drawn from the evidence must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493-94, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002); Conner v. City of Forest Acres, 348 S.C. 454, 462, 560 S.E.2d 606, 610 (2002). 
In ruling on motions for directed verdict and JNOV, the trial court is required to view the evidence and the inferences that reasonably can be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the party opposing the motions and to deny the motions where either the evidence yields more than one inference or its inference is in doubt.Â  Jinks v. Richland County, 355 S.C. 341, 345, 585 S.E.2d 281, 283 (2003).Â  The appellate court will reverse the trial courtâ€™s ruling on a JNOV motion only when there is no evidence to support the ruling or where the ruling is controlled by an error of law.Â  Hinkle v. Natâ€™l Cas. Ins. Co., 354 S.C. 92, 96, 579 S.E.2d 616, 618 (2003).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Summary Judgment on Malicious Prosecution
Appellants argue the trial court erred in granting Respondentâ€™s motion for summary judgment on the malicious prosecution claims.[2]Â  We disagree.Â Â  
â€œ[T]o maintain an action for malicious prosecution, a plaintiff must establish: (1) the institution or continuation of original judicial proceedings; (2) by or at the instance of the defendant; (3) termination of such proceedings in plaintiffâ€™s favor; (4) malice in instituting such proceedings; (5) lack of probable cause; and (6) resulting injury or damage.â€ Parrott v. Plowden Motor Co., 246 S.C. 318, 321, 143 S.E.2d 607, 608 (1965); Eaves v. Broad River Elec. Co-op., Inc., 277 S.C. 475, 477, 289 S.E.2d 414, 415 (1982).Â  An action for malicious prosecution fails if the plaintiff cannot prove each of the required elements by a preponderance of the evidence, including malice and lack of probable cause.Â  Parrott, 246 S.C. at 322, 143 S.E.2d at 609.
Respondent admitted to the institution of original judicial proceedings by its instance, elements 1 and 2, but contends Appellants did not prove the remaining elements of malicious prosecution.
Appellants contend the trial judged erred in finding the original proceedings had not been sufficiently terminated in their favor.Â  Appellants argue that the criminal proceedings were terminated in their favor because the charges were nolle prossed, Respondent has not commenced a federal action, lapse of time, and lack of tangible evidence of the alleged crimes.Â  
First, Appellants failed to establish a favorable determination of their prior criminal charges.Â  In
McKenney v. Jack Eckerd Co., 304 S.C. 21, 22, 402 S.E.2d 887, 888 (1991), the Court held â€œwhere an accused establishes that charges were nolle prossed for reasons which imply or are consistent with innocence, an action for malicious prosecution may be maintained.â€Â  On the underlying charges in the present cases, the reason stated for the nolle prosse was that the arresting agency had chosen to pursue the charges in federal court.Â  This reasoning does not imply and is not consistent with Appellantsâ€™ innocence.
Second, an essential element of malicious prosecution is the institution of judicial proceedings without probable cause against the plaintiff.Â 
Kinton v. Mobile Home Indus., Inc., 274 S.C. 179, 262 S.E.2d 727 (1980).Â  The burden is on the plaintiff to show that the prosecuting person or entity lacked probable cause to pursue a criminal or civil action against him.Â  Parrott, 246 S.C. at 322, 143 S.E.2d at 609.Â  Probable cause means â€œthe extent of such facts and circumstances as would excite the belief in a reasonable mind acting on the facts within the knowledge of the prosecutor that the person charged was guilty of a crime for which he has been charged, and only those facts and circumstances which were or should have been known to the prosecutor at the time he instituted the prosecution should be considered.â€ Â Id.Â  In determining the existence of probable cause, the facts must be â€œregarded from the point of view of the party prosecuting; the question is not
what the actual facts were, but what he honestly believed them to be.â€  Eaves, 277
S.C. at 478, 289 S.E.2d at 415-16 (citing 54 C.J.S. Malicious Prosecution 
Â§ 20, p. 977).  South Carolina
has long embraced the rule that a true bill of indictment is prima facie
evidence of probable cause in an action for malicious prosecution.  Kinton,
274 S.C. at 182, 262 S.E.2d at 728.  Although the question of whether
probable cause exists is ordinarily a jury question, it may be decided as a
matter of law when the evidence yields but one conclusion. Parrott, 246 S.C. at 323, 143 S.E.2d at 609.  
Appellants were indicted by the Allendale County Grand Jury in September 1999.Â  Prior to the arrests on March 25, 1999, Nettles and Baker interviewed Harrison at least three times and interviewed several other inmates who corroborated Harrisonâ€™s allegations.Â  Nettles and Baker also searched bank records of Mole and Vaughan which revealed numerous, large cash deposits and wire transfers during the months prior to the investigation.Â  Viewing the record in the light most favorable to Appellants, Appellants failed to establish a lack of probable cause because the indictments are prima facie evidence of probable cause and because the facts support a finding that Respondent had probable cause to pursue criminal charges.
Third, Appellants did not establish Respondentâ€™s malice in instituting the original proceedings.Â  Malice is defined as â€œthe deliberate intentional doing of an act without just cause or excuse.â€Â  Eaves, 277 S.C. at 479, 289 S.E.2d at 416.Â  Malice does not necessarily mean a defendant acted out of spite, revenge, or with a malignant disposition, although such an attitude certainly may indicate malice.Â  Malice also may proceed from an ill-regulated mind which is not sufficiently cautious before causing injury to another person.Â  Moreover, malice may be implied where the evidence reveals a disregard of the consequences of an injurious act, without reference to any special injury that may be inflicted on another person.Â  Malice also may be implied in the doing of an illegal act for oneâ€™s own gratification or purpose without regard to the rights of others or the injury which may be inflicted on another person.Â  In an action for malicious prosecution, malice may be inferred from a lack of probable cause to institute the prosecution.Â  Margolis v. Telech, 239 S.C. 232, 122 S.E.2d 417, 420 (1961).
The record reveals Respondent conducted an internal investigation based upon an inmateâ€™s allegations that Appellants were trafficking drugs in the Institution.Â  The two primary investigators interviewed Harrison and at least four other inmates prior to the arrests and interviewed no less than 38 inmates at the Institution during the entire investigation.Â  Before completing the investigation, Nettles and Baker discussed the evidence with Waters who thought that arrests should be made based on historical conspiracy.Â  The institution of the original proceedings against Appellants was the result of a thorough investigation, and Appellants failed to establish malice.
We conclude the trial judge properly granted summary judgment for Respondent because Appellants failed to establish termination of the original proceedings in their favor, lack of probable cause, and malice, all elements of malicious prosecution.
II. Directed Verdict on Wrongful Termination
Appellants argue the trial court erred in ruling they had failed to exhaust their administrative remedies and in granting a directed verdict for Respondent on their wrongful termination claims.Â  We disagree.
The general rule is that administrative remedies must be exhausted absent circumstances excusing application of the general rule.Â  Hyde v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Mental Health, 314 S.C. 207, 442 S.E.2d 582 (1994); Andrews Bearing Corp. v. Brady, 261 S.C. 533, 201 S.E.2d 241 (1973).Â  â€œA general exception to the requirement of exhaustion of administrative remedies exists when a party demonstrates that a pursuit of them would be a vain or futile act.â€Â  Moore v. Sumter County Council, 300 S.C. 270, 273-74, 387 S.E.2d 455, 458 (1990) (citing 82 Am.Jur.2d Zoning and Planning Â§ 332 at 903 (1976)). 
Futility, however, must be demonstrated by a showing comparable to the administrative agency taking â€œa hard and fast position that makes an adverse ruling a certainty.â€Â  Thetford Properties IV Ltd. Pâ€™ship v. U.S. Depâ€™t of Hous. and Urban Dev., 907 F.2d 445, 450 (4th Cir. 1990).Â  
The question of whether to require the plaintiff to exhaust administrative remedies is a matter within the sound discretion of the trial judge.Â  Andrews Bearing Corp., 261 S.C. at 536, 201 S.E.2d at 243.Â  A matter within the sound discretion of the trial judge will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Tri County Ice and Fuel Co. v. Palmetto Ice Co., 303 S.C. 237, 242, 399 S.E.2d 779, 782 (1990).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs where the trial judge was controlled by an error of law or where his order is based on factual conclusions that are without evidentiary support.â€ Id.  
Respondent, as a state agency, is governed by the State Employee Grievance Procedure Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 8-17-310 through 380 (1996 & Supp. 2005).Â  Section 8-17-330 provides in pertinent part:

Each agency shall establish an agency employee grievance procedure. . . .A covered employee who wishes to appeal the
decision of the agency grievance procedure to the State Human Resources Director shall file an appeal within ten calendar days
of receipt of the decision from the agency head or his designee or within fifty-five calendar days after the employee files the
grievance with the agency, whichever occurs later.Â  The covered employee or the employeeâ€™s representative shall file the request
in writing with the State Human Resources Director.Â  Failure to file an appeal with the State Human Resources Director within
ten calendar days of the agencyâ€™s final decision or fifty-five calendar days from the initial grievance, whichever occurs later,
constitutes a waiver of the right to appeal. . . . As used in this article, a covered employee may file a grievance or appeal
concerning the following adverse employment actions: terminations, suspensions, involuntary reassignments, and
demotions. . . .A covered employee has the right to appeal to the State Human Resources Director an adverse employment action
involving the issues specified in this section after all administrative remedies to secure relief within the agency have
been exhausted.

Appellants contend the trial court misinterpreted the State Employee Grievance Procedure Act as requiring an employee to appeal to the State Human Resources Director upon an adverse ruling by the agency hearing the appeal.Â  Appellants argue the statute uses permissive language regarding the appeal to the State Human Resources Director.
Appellants further argue the general rule of exhaustion of administrative remedies is inapplicable to them because they have demonstrated the pursuit of such remedies would have been vain or futile.Â  Specifically, Appellant Moleâ€™s appeal was denied by the Director of Respondent; therefore his attempt was futile and because all Appellants were similarly situated, their attempts would have been futile.Â  
Appellantsâ€™ Law, Holmes, Jenkins, and Green voluntarily resigned.Â  Therefore, we affirm the directed verdict for Respondent on their wrongful termination claims because they failed to state a cause of action.[3]Â  See  Troutman v. Facetglas, Inc., 281 S.C. 598, 316 S.E.2d 424 (Ct. App. 1984) (former employee who resigned under alleged threat to fire him did not state a cause of action for wrongful discharge).Â  
Appellantsâ€™ Mole and Vaughan were terminated because conspiracy to traffic crack cocaine violated Respondentâ€™s internal policy regarding employee behavior.Â  Appellants had a grievable action
under the State Employee Grievance Procedure Act which they voluntarily did not appeal.[4]Â  Failure to file an appeal with the State Human Resources Director within the statutory time period constitutes a waiver of the right to appeal.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 8-17-330. Â Furthermore, if Appellants were concerned of bias during the Respondentâ€™s appellate process because Respondent sought the charges, then an appeal to the State Human Resources Director, who was outside the agency, should have allayed any concerns of bias.Â  The trial judge correctly determined their wrongful termination claims were foreclosed under the State Employee Grievance Procedure Act because they did not exhaust their administrative remedies.Â  
III. JNOV on False Imprisonment
Appellants argue the trial judge erred in granting Respondentâ€™s motion for JNOV on the false imprisonment claims.Â  We disagree.
The essence of the tort of false imprisonment consists of depriving a person of his liberty without lawful justification.Â  Jones v. City of Columbia, 301 S.C. 62, 389 S.E.2d 662 (1990); Thomas v. Colonial Stores, Inc., 236 S.C. 95, 113 S.E.2d 337 (1960).Â  To prevail on a claim for false imprisonment, the plaintiff must establish: (1) the defendant restrained the plaintiff, (2) the restraint was intentional, and (3) the restraint was unlawful. 
    Gist v. Berkeley County Sheriffâ€™s Depâ€™t, 336 S.C. 611, 521 S.E.2d 163 (Ct. App. 1999); Jones by Robinson v. Winn-Dixie Greenville, Inc., 318 S.C. 171, 456 S.E.2d 429 (Ct. App. 1995); Caldwell v. K-Mart Corp., 306 S.C. 27, 410 S.E.2d 21 (Ct. App. 1991); see also Jones, 301 S.C. at 64, 389 S.E.2d at 663 (an action for false imprisonment cannot be maintained where one is arrested by lawful authority).
The fundamental issue in determining the lawfulness of an arrest is whether there was probable cause to make the arrest.Â  Gist, 336 S.C. at 615, 521 S.E.2d at 165.Â  Probable cause is defined as a good faith belief that a person is guilty of a crime when this belief rests on such grounds as would induce an ordinarily prudent and cautious man, under the circumstances, to believe likewise.Â  Jones v. City of Columbia, 301 S.C. at 65, 389 S.E.2d at 663.Â  Although the question of whether probable cause exists is ordinarily a jury question, it may be decided as a matter of law when the evidence yields but one conclusion. Parrott, 246 S.C. at 323, 143 S.E.2d at 609.
â€œAll proceedings before magistrates in criminal cases shall be commenced on information under oath, plainly and substantially setting forth the offense charged, upon which, and only which, shall a warrant of arrest issue.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 22-3-710 (1989).Â  A warrant affidavit that is â€œinsufficient in itself to establish probable cause may be supplemented before a magistrate by sworn oral testimony.â€Â  State v. Crane, 296 S.C. 336, 338, 372 S.E.2d 587, 588 (1988).
Because Respondent admitted the first and second elements, the determinative issue is whether probable cause to make the arrests existed.Â  
Appellants assert their situation is similar to Gist.Â  Gist sued the Berkeley County Sheriffâ€™s Department for false arrest and false imprisonment.Â  The sheriffâ€™s department conceded the affidavit supporting the warrant for Gistâ€™s arrest did not establish probable cause, but relied on the investigating officerâ€™s testimony that he orally told the judge information that was not referenced in the affidavit to establish probable cause.Â  However, the record did not contain any evidence as to whether the affidavit was accompanied by sworn, oral testimony before the judge. The Court of Appeals reversed and remanded the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment for the sheriffâ€™s department.Â  The court found viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to Gist, a genuine issue of material fact existed as to whether the judge was presented sworn, oral testimony concerning a photographic lineup when the probable cause determination was made.Â  Gist, 336 S.C. at 615-17, 521 S.E.2d at 165-66.Â  
In the present case, the magistrate, who issued the arrest warrants, testified he routinely conducted an oral report, under oath, in addition to the affidavits presented to him before making a probable cause determination.Â  Nettles testified she and Baker gave sworn, oral testimony to the magistrate, which included examples of corroboration of Harrisonâ€™s allegations.[5]Â  
The present situation is distinguishable from Gist because the record contains evidence the affidavits were supplemented with sworn, oral testimony.Â  The facts known to the magistrate at the time of the probable cause determination included information from the affidavits[6] and from sworn, oral testimony.Â  We conclude, as a matter of law, the facts known to the magistrate â€œwould induce an ordinarily prudent and cautious man, under the circumstances, to believeâ€ that Appellants had committed the offenses.  Jones, 301 S.C. at 65, 389 S.E.2d at 663.Â  The trial judge correctly granted Respondentâ€™s JNOV because Appellants failed to establish the restraint was unlawful. 
CONCLUSION
We affirm the trial courtâ€™s grant of Respondentâ€™s motions for summary judgment on the malicious prosecution claims and for JNOV on the false imprisonment claims.Â  We affirm as modified the directed verdict for Respondent on the wrongful termination claims.
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, J., and Acting Justice Clyde N. Davis, Jr., concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., concurring in part and dissenting in part in a separate opinion.
 JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I concur in part and dissent in part.Â  I agree with the majority opinion that the grant of summary judgment on the malicious-prosecution claims and the directed verdict on the wrongful-termination claims should be affirmed.Â  I respectfully dissent from the affirmance of JNOV on the false-imprisonment claims, because the evidence in the record yields at least one inference that supports the juryâ€™s verdict.Â  See Strange v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Highways and Pub. Transp., 314 S.C. 427, 429-30, 445 S.E.2d 439, 440 (1994) (providing the standard for ruling on motions for
JNOV).  
The lawful-authority determination here turns on whether the insufficient warrant affidavits were sufficiently supplemented by sworn oral testimony pursuant to State v. Crane, 296 S.C. 336, 338, 372 S.E.2d 587, 588 (1988).Â  If so, then the warrants were valid and lawful authority to arrest was present.Â  If not, then the warrants were not issued pursuant to legal process, and lawful authority to arrest was absent.Â  The relevant evidence is the trial testimony of the magistrate and the trial testimony of Investigator Nettles.Â  As stated in the majority opinion, â€œthe magistrate, who issued the arrest warrants, testified he routinely conducted an oral report, under oath, in addition to the affidavits presented to him before making a probable cause determination.Â  Nettles testified she and Baker gave sworn, oral testimony to the magistrate, which included examples of corroboration of Harrisonâ€™s allegations.â€Â  The majority holds that this trial testimony proves the warrant affidavits were orally supplemented.Â  In so holding, the majority necessarily passes on the credibility of witness.Â  I disagree with the holding because it was within the juryâ€™s province to believe or disbelieve this trial testimony.Â  See Curcio v. Caterpillar, Inc., 355 S.C. 316, 585 S.E.2d 272 (2003) (holding that â€œ[w]hen considering a JNOV, neither an appellate court, nor the trial court has authority to decide credibility issues or to resolve conflicts in the testimony or the evidence") (internal quotation omitted).Â  In my opinion, the evidence yields at least one reasonable inference that the warrant affidavits were not orally supplemented.Â  That inference supports a conclusion that the warrants were not issued pursuant to legal process and that lawful authority was therefore absent.Â  Consequently, I would reverse the grant of JNOV and reinstate the juryâ€™s verdict on Appellantsâ€™ false-imprisonment claims.Â Â  

[1] S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 15-78-10 to -200 (2005).
[2] Â In support of its motion, Respondent presented the following evidence: affidavits of Nettles, Miro, Elizabeth Stewart, Robin Gracien, and Magistrate Walter Griffin; deposition of Baker; and several internal policies of Respondent.Â  Appellants did not file additional evidence.
[3] Â This court may affirm the trial court based on any ground found
in the record. Rule 220(c), SCACR; Iâ€™On, LLC v. Town of Mount Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 418, 526 S.E.2d 716, 722 (2000).
[4] Â See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 8-17-320(7), -330 (defining â€œgrievanceâ€ to include dismissal from employment).
[5]Â  At trial, Nettles testified as follows: 
Q:Â Â Â Â Â  And did you give sworn testimony to?
A:Â Â Â Â Â  Yes, sir, both myself and Officer Baker or Investigator Baker did.
Q:Â Â Â Â Â  And did you tell [the magistrate] essentially the same things that
you told the Court here today?
A:Â Â Â Â Â  Yes, sir, I told [the magistrate] essentially what is written on the
affidavits of each warrant, yes, sir.
Q:Â Â Â Â Â  Did you tell him about the corroboration of Mr. Harrison?
A:Â Â Â Â Â  Yes, sir.
Q:Â Â Â Â Â  And give him the same kinds of examples that youâ€™ve given us
here today?
A:Â Â Â Â Â  Yes, sir, I did.
[6]Â  For example, the affidavit supporting the warrant for Law provides: 
That between May 1997 thru March 25, 1999 while at Allendale Correctional Institution located in Allendale County South Carolina, the defendant Anthony F. Law, did violate statute 44-53-375 of the South Carolina Code of Laws, 1976 as amended, Conspiracy To Traffic Crack Cocaine Greater Than 100 Grams.Â  In that the defendant did willfully, unlawfully, and feloniously conspire with Harry Jenkins, Mark Holmes, Vondeste Mole, and Arthur Vaughan, to Traffic Crack Cocaine Greater Than 100 Grams with a Confidential Reliable Informant (CRI) at the Allendale Correctional Institution during the period of May 1997 thru March 25, 1999.Â  A statement was provided by the Confidential Reliable Informant which has been determined factual through corroboration of the facts.Â  Investigators Joseph Baker and Melissa [Nettles] are witnesses to prove the same.Â  All of which are against the Law, Peace, and Dignity of the State of South Carolina.Â
