title: Brandt v. Gooding
description: This Court held that a deposition is the type of judicial setting that constitutes the presence of the court.  As a result, the Court upheld the trial courtâ€™s decision granting summary judgment, and issuing criminal and civil contempt sanctions.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Donald M. Brandt, Individually and as the Personal Representative of the Estate of Janice N. Brandt, Deceased,
Appellant,
v.
Elizabeth K. Gooding and Gooding & Gooding, P.A.,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal from Allendale County
Â Paul M. Burch, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26135
Heard January 20, 2005 - Filed April 10, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jack B. Swerling, of Columbia; and Richard A. Harpootlian, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Amanda G. Steinmeyer and Daniel A. Speights, both of Speights & Runyan, of Hampton; and Joel W. Collins, Jr., and Joseph S. McCue, both of Collins & Lacy, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  This is a legal malpractice action.Â  The trial court granted summary judgment, found the plaintiff to be in contempt, and dismissed the complaint as a sanction.Â  In addition, the trial court sentenced the plaintiff to six months imprisonment, issued a restraining order, and awarded court costs and attorneysâ€™ fees to the defendant.Â  The plaintiff appealed.Â  We hold that the trial court properly granted summary judgment, and properly issued criminal and civil contempt sanctions.Â  Additionally, the court correctly awarded costs.Â  Therefore, we affirm.
Factual / Procedural Background
This legal malpractice action arose out of a land transaction in Allendale County.Â  Donald M. Brandt (Brandt) sued Elizabeth K. Gooding, the law firm of Gooding & Gooding (Gooding), the lender, Edisto Farm Credit Service (Edisto Farm), and Ronald L. Summers (Summers), Senior Vice President of Edisto Farm, for breach of fiduciary duty, negligence, and civil conspiracy stemming from Goodingâ€™s representation of Brandt in the land transaction.[1]
In 1999, the court dismissed the claims against Summers and Edisto Farm.Â  The court found that those parties were sham parties named in the complaint by Brandt to establish venue in Orangeburg County.Â  As a result, venue was transferred to Allendale County.
During discovery, Brandt produced a document (Edisto Farm Letter), which appeared to have been sent by Summers of Edisto Farm to Brandt on September 18, 1995.Â  Brandt also provided the letter to his malpractice expert, Professor John Freeman.Â  The letter was introduced in Professor Freemanâ€™s deposition and used by him to opine that Gooding had committed malpractice.Â  Brandt first caused the document to enter the case on April 3, 2001 when he provided a supplemental response to a request to produce.Â  In addition, Brandt introduced the deposition into evidence in the case as an attachment to his Memorandum in Support of Motion for Reconsideration on January 18, 2002. 
The document, if authentic, would have imputed knowledge to Gooding of a conflict of interest related to the representation of Brandt in the land transaction.Â  But Gooding claimed that the document was fraudulent, and as a result, requested a hearing to determine whether the document was authentic.Â  In addition, Gooding asked the court to issue a citation of contempt if the document proved to be a forgery.Â  However, the circuit court judge delayed a contempt hearing until it could be determined if the document was authentic.
In subsequent motions before a second circuit court judge (trial court), Gooding moved for summary judgment, dismissal of the cause of action, and contempt.Â  At the hearing on the second motions, Gooding presented the testimony of Marvin Dawson (Dawson), an expert in document examination and authenticity.Â  Dawson opined that the letter was fraudulent.
Dawson testified that the Edisto Farm Letter was printed on a type of paper that was not developed until 2000, almost five years after the letter allegedly was sent.Â  In addition, Dawson found that the letter did not contain the appropriate watermark.Â  In a report, Dawson cited numerous inconsistencies and characteristics indicating that the document was a forgery.
Although Brandt was not represented by counsel, Brandt cross-examined Dawson as to the authenticity of the document.Â  Brandt testified that he could not find anyone to represent him.Â  He did, however, bring a potential expert witness to court, but decided not to put the witness on the stand.Â  
The trial court found Brandt introduced a fraudulent document into a court proceeding.Â  As a result, the trial court dismissed the complaint with prejudice as a sanction.Â  In addition, the trial court granted summary judgment.Â  The trial court also held Brandt in criminal contempt for perpetrating a fraud upon the court and sentenced him to six-months imprisonment.Â  Finally, the trial court awarded court and attorneysâ€™ fees to Gooding.Â  Subsequent to the trial courtâ€™s finding that the Summers letter was fraudulent, Professor Freeman withdrew his opinion, stating:

The Courtâ€™s meticulously detailed Order finds that the Brandt letter was â€œfabricated, forged and fraudulent,â€ and the [sic] Mr. Brandt committed a fraud on the Court in bringing the evidence forward . . . it appears to me that my services were used in an attempt to perpetrate a fraud on the Court.
. . . . 
. . . I have no choice but to withdraw and disaffirm my opinion testimony offered in the Gooding case.

Brandt filed a motion for reconsideration.Â  The trial court suspended the sentence pending review.Â  Upon review, the trial court sustained its earlier ruling and Brandt was taken into custody.Â  Another motion for reconsideration was filed and denied.Â  Brandt appealed.
This Court certified the following issues for review from the court of appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b),
SCACR:

  
    
      
        I. 
         Did the trial court have the authority to hold a contempt proceeding even though the first judge ruled that a contempt hearing should be delayed?
          
      
      
        II. 
        Did the trial court err in granting summary judgment?
          
      
      
        III.
         Did the trial court err in dismissing the complaint as a sanction for civil contempt of court?
          
      
      
        IV.   
         Did the trial court err in holding Brandt in direct criminal contempt?
          
      
      
        V.  
         Did the trial court err in issuing a restraining order?
          
      
      
        VI.   
         Did the trial court err in awarding attorneysâ€™ fees and costs?
      
    
  

Law
/ Analysis
I.                 
Authority of the Trial Court
Brandt argues that the trial court did not have subject matter jurisdiction to grant summary judgment or cite him for contempt of court.[2]Â  We disagree.
When determining whether to grant summary judgment, a court must examine both the facts and the law.Â  Royster Co. v. Eastern Distribution, Inc., 301 S.C. 18, 20, 389 S.E.2d 863, 864 (1990).Â  Because a court must conduct the examination of law and facts, such an examination constitutes a trial.Â  Id.Â  As a result, a summary judgment motion, when granted, constitutes the final determination of all the issues that exist between the parties.Â  Id.Â  See also Baird v. Charleston, 333 S.C. 519, 529, 511 S.E.2d 69, 74 (1999) (holding that summary judgment is an adjudication on the merits).
In support of his argument that the trial court did not have the authority to rule on contempt, Brandt relies on authority that prohibits one circuit court judge from reversing the standing order of another circuit court judge.Â  For example, in Cook v. Taylor, this Court held that a circuit court judge does not have the authority to reverse another circuit court judgeâ€™s determination of the proper mode of trial.Â  272 S.C. 536, 538, 252 S.E.2d 923, 924 (1979).Â  Moreover, a circuit court judge cannot deny the use of an amended complaint in light of an order of another circuit judge that permitted use of the amended complaint.Â  Enoree Baptist Church v. Fletcher, 287 S.C. 602, 603, 340 S.E.2d 546, 547 (1986).
In the present case, the first judge issued an order on Goodingâ€™s motion for a rule to show cause as to whether the Edisto Farm Letter was authentic.Â  If the letter was proven to be a forgery, Gooding wanted to go forward with contempt proceedings against Brandt.Â  The first judge dismissed the petition without prejudice because a contempt proceeding was premature until after the documentâ€™s authenticity was determined.Â  In addition, the first judge established a procedure to examine the document and examples of similar documents from Edisto Farm.Â  In essence, the first judge took the logical steps to leave the issue of contempt to be addressed after such a determination had been made.Â  Gooding then brought subsequent motions before the trial court with testimony from an expert that the document was a forgery.Â  In the second battery of motions, Gooding moved for summary judgment, for citation of contempt, and for dismissal of the complaint.Â  After a hearing, the trial court granted summary judgment, dismissed the complaint, and held Brandt in contempt of court.
Because the first judge delayed a contempt hearing, the trial court did not reverse a standing order of the first judge.Â  Instead, the trial court acted in accordance with the steps outlined by the first judge and ruled on the issue of contempt after the documentâ€™s authenticity could be determined.Â  Accordingly, we hold that the trial court had the authority to grant summary judgment.Â  
II.               Summary Judgment
Brandt contends that the trial court erred in granting summary judgment in favor of Gooding.Â  We disagree.
Summary judgment is appropriate when it is clear that there is no genuine issue of material fact, and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Summer v. Carpenter, 328 S.C. 36, 42, 492 S.E.2d 55, 58 (1997).Â  In determining whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Id.Â  The party seeking summary judgment has the burden of clearly establishing the absence of a genuine issue of material fact.Â  Baughman v. Am. Tel. and Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 115, 410 S.E.2d 537, 545 (1991).
In a legal malpractice action, a plaintiff must prove that (1) the defendant was negligent, (2) the defendantâ€™s negligence proximately caused the plaintiffâ€™s injuries, and (3) damages resulted.Â  Summer, 328 S.C. at 42, 492 S.E.2d at 58.
In the present case, the trial court granted summary judgment on the ground that Gooding did not proximately cause Brandt any injury.Â  In addition, the trial court found that because the case against Lombard in the Aiken County matter settled, Gooding was released from any liability.Â  Further, the trial court found Brandt could not show damages.Â  To the contrary, Brandt profited from the sale of outparcels from the land purchased in the transaction involved in this legal malpractice action.
Because Brandt did not suffer any injury, we hold that the trial court did not err in granting summary judgment.
III.          
Civil Contempt 
Brandt contends that the trial court erred ordering civil contempt and dismissing the complaint as a sanction for the contempt.Â  We disagree.
Courts have the power to punish for both civil and criminal contempt.Â  In re Brown, 333 S.C. 414, 420, 511 S.E.2d 351, 355 (1998).Â  On appeal, a decision regarding contempt should be reversed only if it is without evidentiary support or the trial judge has abused his discretion.Â  Stone v. Reddix-Smalls, 295 S.C. 514, 516, 369 S.E.2d 840, 840-41 (1988) (citing Means v. Means, 277 S.C. 428, 431, 288 S.E.2d 811, 812-813 (1982)).Â  
A defendant may move to dismiss the plaintiffâ€™s complaint on the ground that the plaintiff has no right to relief based on the facts and the law.Â  Rule 41, SCRCP; Shepard v. S.C. Dept. of Corrections, 299 S.C. 370, 372, 385 S.E.2d 35, 36 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  Furthermore, a complaint may be dismissed with prejudice for failure to comply with these rules or any other order of the court.Â  Rule 41(b), SCRCP
In the present case, the trial court found Brandt to be in contempt of court for introducing a fraudulent document.Â  In response, the trial court dismissed the complaint as a sanction for perpetrating a fraud upon the court.
We hold that the trial court did not abuse its discretion in dismissing the complaint as a sanction for civil contempt.Â  Dismissal of the complaint is a proper sanction against a complainant who submits fraudulent documents to the court.Â  Therefore, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision. 
IV.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Criminal Contempt
Brandt contends the trial court erred in holding him in direct criminal contempt.Â  We disagree.
It is within the trial courtâ€™s discretion to punish by fine or imprisonment all contempts of authority before the court.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-5-320 (1976).Â  In addition, courts have the inherent power to punish for offenses that are calculated to obstruct, degrade, and undermine the administration of justice.Â  State ex rel. McLeod v. Hite, 272 S.C. 303, 305, 251 S.E.2d 746, 747 (1979).
Direct contempt involves contemptuous conduct in the presence of the court.Â  State v. Kennerly, 337 S.C. 617, 620, 524 S.E.2d 837, 838 (1999).Â  A person may be found guilty of direct contempt if the conduct interferes with judicial proceedings, exhibits disrespect for the court, or hampers the parties or witnesses.Â  State v. Havelka, 285 S.C. 388, 389, 330 S.E.2d 288 (1985).Â  Direct contempt that occurs in the courtâ€™s presence may be immediately adjudged and sanctioned summarily.Â  Intâ€™l Union, United Mine Workers of Am. v. Bagwell, 512 U.S. 821, 827 (1994).
â€œSouth Carolina courts have always taken a liberal and expansive view of the â€˜presenceâ€™ and â€˜courtâ€™ requirements.â€Â  Kennerly, 337 S.C. at 620, 524 S.E.2d at 838.Â  The â€œpresence of the courtâ€ extends beyond the mere physical presence of the judge or the courtroom to encompass all elements of the system.Â  Id. 
This Court has recognized that depositions are judicial proceedings and are within the â€œpresence of the court.â€Â  Matter of Golden, 329 S.C. 335, 496 S.E.2d 619 (1998).Â  In Golden, the Court held that â€œalthough a deposition is not conducted in a courtroom in the presence of a judge, it is nonetheless a judicial setting.â€Â  Because there is no presiding authority, it is even more incumbent upon attorneys to conduct themselves in a professional and civil manner during a deposition.Â  Id. at 343, 496 S.E.2d at 623.
Â In the present case, the record shows that Brandt presented a fraudulent document to the court.Â  The document was introduced at the deposition of Professor John Freeman.Â  In addition, the deposition was introduced into evidence in the case as an attachment to his Memorandum in Support of Motion for Reconsideration.Â  Further, the record shows that Brandt was the sole cause of the introduction of the document into this case when he provided a supplemental response to the request to produce one day before Professor Freemanâ€™s deposition.Â  We hold that the introduction of the document into the deposition constituted an introduction of the document into the presence of the court, warranting a citation for direct contempt.
Therefore, we hold that the trial court did not err in citing Brandt for direct criminal contempt.Â Â Â  
V.               Restraining Order
Brandt argues that the trial court abused its discretion by issuing a restraining order.Â  We disagree.
The decision of whether to issue a restraining order is within the trial judgeâ€™s discretion.Â  State v. Hill, 266 S.C. 49, 52, 221 S.E.2d 398, 399 (1976).
In the present case, the record indicates that the judge did not abuse his discretion when he issued a restraining order.Â  Brandt testified that he would spend ten years and a million dollars to get justice against Summers and Edisto Farm Credit.Â  Further, Brandt used threatening conduct toward parties involved in the litigation.Â  For example, Brandt told Ronald Summers, after he was dismissed from the lawsuit, that he â€œwasnâ€™t out of the woods yet.â€
The issuance of a restraining order was arguably necessary to prevent Brandt from harassing Gooding and other parties involved in the litigation.Â  Therefore, we hold that the trial court did not abuse its discretion.
VI.          
Fees and Costs 
Brandt contends that the trial court erred in awarding attorneysâ€™ fees and costs.Â  We disagree.
An award of attorneysâ€™ fees and costs is a discretionary matter not to be overturned absent abuse by the trial court.Â  Donahue v. Donahue, 299 S.C. 353, 365, 384 S.E.2d 741, 748 (1989).Â  An award for civil contempt is appropriate when a party has caused unnecessary litigious activity as a result of the contemptuous behavior.Â  Curlee v. Howe, 277 S.C. 377, 386, 287 S.E.2d 915, 920 (1982).
In the present case, Brandt presented a fraudulent document.Â  The introduction of this document unnecessarily prolonged this case.Â  Therefore, the award of fees and costs is an appropriate award because of the unnecessary litigation directly related to the introduction of the letter.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the award.
Conclusion
In sum, we hold that summary judgment was proper.Â  Additionally, the citations for civil and criminal contempt were proper.Â  Finally, the trial court did not abuse its discretion in issuing a restraining order and awarding attorneysâ€™ fees and costs.Â  Accordingly, the ruling of the trial court is affirmed.
MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] Brandt also sued the Lombard Corporation (Lombard) in Aiken County.Â  Lombard was a partner in the land transaction with Brandt.Â  The parties settled.
[2] The circuit court has subject matter jurisdiction in this matter.Â  See Johnson v. S.C. Dept. of Labor Licensing and Regulation, Op. No. 26015 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed July 25, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 30 at 41) (outlining the history of this Courtâ€™s restrictive view of subject mater jurisdiction); Dove v. Gold Kist, 314 S.C. 235, 442 S.E.2d 598 (1994) (stating that subject matter jurisdiction is the power to hear and determine cases of the general class to which the proceedings in question belong); S.C. Const. Art. V, Â§ 11 (stating that the circuit court is the general trial court and has original jurisdiction in civil and criminal matters).Â  As a result, we address the issue with regard to whether the circuit court had the authority to rule on the issue of summary judgment and contempt.Â

description: The issue on appeal is whether or not the Court of Appeals erred in utilizing the â€œlost volume sellerâ€ doctrine?
text:
Collins


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Collins Entertainment Corporation, Respondent,
v.
Coats and Coats Rental Amusement, d/b/a Ponderosa Bingo and Shipwatch Bingo, Wayne Coats, individually, and American Bingo & Gaming Corporation,
Defendants,
Of whom American Bingo & Gaming Corporation is
Petitioner.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Roger M. Young, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26136
Heard April 19, 2005 - Filed April 10, 2006Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
C. Mitchell Brown, Zoe Sanders Nettles,Â  and William C. Wood, all of Nelson Mullins Riley & Scarborough, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Stephen L. Brown, Edward D. Buckley, Jr., Matthew Kiel Mahoney, all of Young Clement Rivers & Tisdale, of Charleston, and Timothy G. Quinn, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE WALLER: We granted a writ of certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion in Collins Ent. Corp. v. Coats & Coats Rental Amuse., 355 S.C. 125, 584 S.E.2d 120 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The sole issue on certiorari is whether the Court of Appeals erred in utilizing the â€œlost volume sellerâ€ doctrine to calculate damages.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In 1996, Collins Entertainment Corporation (Collins) contracted to lease video poker machines to two bingo hall operations known as Ponderosa Bingo and Shipwatch Bingo.[1]Â  The six-year lease required that any purchaser of the premises assume the lease.Â  In 1997, American Bingo and Gaming Corporation (American) purchased the assets of the bingo parlors.Â  American failed to assume the lease and removed Collinsâ€™ machines from the premises.Â  Collins brought this action against American alleging unfair trade practices, civil conspiracy, and intentional interference with contract.Â  The matter was referred to a master in equity for trial.Â  The master found American liable for intentional interference with contract and awarded Collins actual damages of $157,449.66 and punitive damages of $1,569,013.00.[2]Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed.Â  Collins Ent. Corp. v. Coats & Coats Rental Amuse., 355 S.C. 125, 584 S.E.2d 120 (Ct. App. 2003).
ISSUE
Did the Court of Appeals err in utilizing the â€œlost volume sellerâ€ doctrine to hold Collins did not have a duty to mitigate its damages?Â  
DISCUSSION
Comment f to Section 347 of the Restatement (Second) of Contracts states, in part, â€œif the injured party could and would have entered into the subsequent contract, even if the contract had not been broken, and could have had the benefit of both, he can be said to have lost volume and the subsequent transaction is not a substitute for the broken contract.â€Â  This theory of damages has come to be known as the â€œlost volume sellerâ€ doctrine.[3]Â  A lost volume seller is one whose willingness and ability to supply is, as a practical matter, unlimited in comparison to the demand for the product.Â  Thus, â€œ[t]he lost volume seller theory allows [for the] recovery of lost profits despite resale of the services that were the subject of the terminated contract if the seller . . . can prove that he would have entered into both transactions but for the breach.â€Â  Gianetti v. Norwalk Hosp., 833 A.2d 891 (Conn. 2003).Â  See also Comeq, Inc. v. Mitternight Boiler Works, 456 So.2d 264, 268-69 (Ala. 1984) (the reason for the rule is based on the idea that the lost volume seller would have received two profits, not just one, if the buyer had not breached, so that a recovery of both profits is necessary to put the seller in as good a position as if there had been no breach).Â  Although the lost volume seller theory is commonly understood to apply to contracts involving the sale of goods, it applies with equal force to contracts involving the performance of personal services.Â  Id. citing 22 Am.Jur.2d 592, Damages Â§ 509 (1988).Â  Whether a seller is a lost volume seller is a question of fact.Â  Bill's Coal Co. v. Board of Public Utilities, 887 F.2d 242, 245 (10th Cir.1989); Rodriguez v. Learjet, Inc., 833 A.2d 891, 897 (Kan. 1997); Restatement (Second) of Contracts Â§ 347, Comment f (1979).Â  
American asserts adoption of the lost volume seller doctrine eliminates a sellerâ€™s duty to mitigate damages.Â  It contends we should adopt the position advanced by the Pennsylvania Supreme Court in Northeastern Vending Company v. PDO, Inc., 606 A.2d 936 (Pa. 1992), in which the court declined to adopt the lost volume seller doctrine stating, summarily, that it would erode the duty to mitigate damages.[4]Â  We decline to adopt the Pennsylvania approach because we do not find the doctrine erodes the duty to mitigate damages.Â  On the contrary, the doctrine realizes that in certain situations, even where a buyer does mitigate, if the seller would have made the second sale in any event, then the â€œlost volumeâ€ measure of damages places him in the same position he would have been had the buyer not repudiated.[5]Â  As the Court in Davis Chemical v. Diasonics Inc., 826 F.2d 678, 683, n. 3 (7th Cir. 1987), stated, â€œby definition, a lost volume seller cannot mitigate damages through resale. Resale does not reduce a lost volume sellerâ€™s damages because the breach has still resulted in its losing one sale and a corresponding profit.â€ See also Storage Technology Corp. v. Trust Co., 842 F.2d 54, 56 n. 2 (3rd Cir.1988) (pointing out that resale does not make a lost-volume seller whole); Matthews, infra,Â  51 U. Miami L.Rev. at 1214 (noting that the philosophical heart of the lost volume theory is that the seller would have generated a second sale irrespective of the buyerâ€™s breach such that it follows that the lost volume seller cannot possibly mitigate damages).
Further, we find the legislatureâ€™s adoption of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2A-528(2) is consistent with adoption of the lost volume seller doctrine.Â  Section 36-2A-528(2) (dealing with leased goods)[6] tracks the language of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-708(2) (sellerâ€™s damages for sales).Â  Section 36-2-708 clearly tracks the provisions of the Uniform Commercial Code section (UCC Â§ 2-708(2)) upon which the lost volume seller doctrine is premised.Â  See generally, Jerald B. Holisky, Finding the Lost Volume Seller; Two Independent Sales Deserve Two Profits Under Illinois Law, 22 J. Marshall L. Rev. 363 (Winter 1988) (recognizing that the lost profit seller doctrine emanates from UCC 2-708(2)); Jonathan J. Lautt, Contract Law: A Clean Start for Lost Volume Lessees, 34 Washburn L.J. 136 (Fall 1994) (recognizing that section 82-2-708 (2) of the Kansas Statutes codifies the lost volume recovery for the sale of goods).Â  By adoption of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2A-528(2), we find the Legislature has tacitly approved of the lost volume seller doctrine.Â Â  
American next asserts there is insufficient evidence in the record to demonstrate that Collins is a lost volume seller.Â  We disagree.Â  There is no one set test to determine whether one is a lost volume seller.Â  According to one commentator: 

Professor Harris has developed three main requirements that a lost volume seller must meet: (1) the person who bought the resold entity would have been solicited by the plaintiff had there been no breach or resale; (2) the solicitation would have been successful; and (3) the plaintiff could have performed that additional contract.Â  Most American courts and commentators have adopted these requirements.[7]  

Saidov, The Methods for Limiting Damages Under the Vienna Convention on Contracts for the Sale of Goods, 14 Pace Intâ€™l L. Rev. 307 (Fall 2002), citing Jerald B. Holisky, Finding the Lost Volume Seller: Two Independent Sales Deserve Two Profits under Illinois Law, 22 J. Marshall L. Rev. 363, 375 (1998).
Here, there is testimony in the record which indicates that Collins had surplus machines on hand and that, had another location been available, it could and would have supplied those locations with video machines.Â  Further, Collins did place 19 of the 20 machines which were removed from Shipwatch and Ponderosa into other premises.Â  As found by the Master, it is patent that Collins had excess inventory with which to supply and rotate machines through all of its customers.Â  
American argues there has been no showing by Collins that the specific type of machines removed from the Shipwatch and Ponderosa were available at its warehouses, such that it has failed in its burden to demonstrate it had excess capacity.Â  We disagree.Â  Initially, although American argued there was insufficient evidence of excess capacity below, it made no argument with respect to the specific types of machines at issue.Â  Accordingly, as this specific argument was not raised below, it is not preserved.Â  In any event, Collins presented testimony from its assistant comptroller for accounting that, although there were ten machines in each location (i.e., the Shipwatch and Ponderosa), a total of 48 machines rotated through the locations.Â  Livingston also testified that â€œwe had machines in the warehouse that could have easily replaced these 48 at the 130 locations.â€ Livingstonâ€™s testimony is sufficient to establish that Collins had more supply capacity of these machines than it had demand.Â  Moreover, the lease agreement between Collins and Coats and Coats Rental gives Collins the right to furnish â€œall video game terminals and all coin operated music and amusement machines, to include a special multi-player Black Jack/Poker unit.â€Â  We find no requirement (other than one multi-player poker unit) that Collins place any particular machines on the premises, such that Collins was free to have utilized any of its machines at the Ponderosa and Shipwatch.Â  Accordingly, Collins was not required to demonstrate excess capacity as to a specific type of machine.Â  
CONCLUSION
Contrary to the arguments raised by American, we find adoption of the lost volume seller doctrine does not eliminate a sellerâ€™s duty to mitigate his damages.Â  The doctrine simply recognizes that, in situations in which the seller has excess capacity and would, in any event, have made both sales, the lost volume measure of damages is necessary to place the seller in the same position he would have been had the buyer not repudiated.Â  Further, there is sufficient evidence to demonstrate that Collins was, in fact, a lost volume seller in this case.Â  Accordingly, the opinion of the Court of Appeals utilizing the lost volume seller doctrine is affirmed.[8]
 AFFIRMED.
 MOORE, J., concurs.Â  PLEICONES, J., concurring in a separate opinion. TOAL, C.J., dissenting in a separate opinion in which BURNETT, J., concurs.Â  
JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I concur in the majorityâ€™s express adoption of the lost-volume-seller doctrine and in the result.Â  A lost-volume seller, or lessor, cannot mitigate his damages, so there is no duty to try.Â  Evidence in the record supports the finding that Collins is a lost-volume lessor.Â  I write separately because my analysis differs from the majorityâ€™s on some issues.
In note 8, the majority asserts that the issue whether the lost-volume-seller doctrine can apply in contract but not tort, an issue addressed in the dissent, is not preserved.Â  I disagree.Â  The issue is within the ambit of the main issue in the case ... whether the doctrine ever applies.Â  I nonetheless disagree with the dissent that the lost-volume-seller doctrine can apply in breach-of-contract cases but not in tortious-interference cases.Â  
As noted in the dissent:Â  â€œThe nexus between the two causes of action [breach of contract and tortious interference with contract] is the breach of the contract, for ... breach of the contract is an element of both causes of action.Â  This is the element from which the injured partyâ€™s actual damages flow on both the contract and tort claims.â€Â  Collins Music Co. v. Smith, 332 S.C. 145, 147, 503 S.E.2d 481, 481 (Ct. App. 1998) (quoting Ross v. Holton, 640 S.W.2d 166, 173 (Mo. Ct. App. 1982)).Â  In sum, contract damages are part of tortious-interference damages.Â  The nature of the claim, whether contract or tort, does not affect the method of determining the damages flowing from the plaintiffâ€™s loss of contract expectations, and the lost-volume-seller doctrine merely provides one such method.Â  There is no reason that the doctrine cannot apply in a tortious-interference case. 
With respect to the dissentâ€™s conclusion that Collins has received a double recovery, I agree, but the writ of certiorari that we granted did not encompass the issue.Â  The only issues before us are whether the lost-volume-seller doctrine can apply in South Carolina and whether it applies in this case.
For the reasons above, I concur in the result reached by the majority.
CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  In my view, the â€œlost volume sellerâ€ doctrine should not be adopted and applied in this case.Â  Moreover, in my view, the court of appeals erred in affirming the trial courtâ€™s calculation of damages.Â  Therefore, I would reverse and remand.Â Â Â  
The lost volume seller doctrine is a measure of damages applied in cases involving breach-of-contract claims. See, e.g., Gianetti v. Norwalk Hosp., 833 A.2d 891 (Conn. 2003); Jetz Serv. Co., Inc. v. Salina Properties, 865 P.2d 1051 (Ct. App. Kan. 1993).Â  
The present case, however, involves an allegation of tortious interference with contract.[9]Â  As its name implies, tortious interference with contract is a tort, requiring the plaintiff to establish, among other things, intentional procurement of the contractâ€™s breach. Â See, e.g., Camp v. Spring Mortg. Co., 310 S.C. 514, 517, 426 S.E.2d 304, 305 (1993); Todd v. S.C. Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co., 287 S.C. 190, 192-93, 336 S.E.2d 472, 473 (1985).Â  Consequently, damages for tortious interference of contract â€œare not measured by contract rules.â€Â  Collins Music Co., Inc. v. Smith, 332 S.C. 145, 147, 503 S.E.2d 481, 482 (Ct. App. 1998) (quoting Ross v. Holton, 640 S.W.2d 166 (Mo. Ct. App. 1982)).Â  
Because the lost volume seller doctrine applies in breach-of-contract cases only, and because the present case involves a tort, the court of appeals, in my view, erred in adopting and applying the doctrine.Â  
Moreover, in my view, the court of appeals erred in affirming the trial courtâ€™s calculation of damages.Â  A plaintiff may not recover twice for the same injury.Â  Riddle v. City of Greenville, 251 S.C. 473, 478, 163 S.E.2d 462, 464 (1968); Collins Music Co., Inc. v. Smith, 332 S.C. 145, 147, 503 S.E.2d 481, 482 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  In Smith, Collins brought an action against one party for breach of contract and against a second party for tortious interference with contractual relations.Â  The jury awarded $10,000 in actual damages on the breach-of-contract claim and $10,000 in actual damages for the tortious-interference claim.Â  After granting the defendantsâ€™ motions to amend the judgment, the trial court entered a single judgment of $10,000.Â  The court of appeals affirmed.Â  Id.
In affirming the award of a single judgment, the court explained as follows:

While the causes of action [of breach and tortious interference] involve separate and distinct wrongful acts committed by different parties, there are important commonalities which affect the damages question. The nexus between the two causes of action is the breach of the contract, for . . . breach of the contract is an element of both causes of action. This is the element from which the injured partyâ€™s actual damages flow on both the contract and tort claims. This does not mean, however, that the measure of actual damages on both causes of action are coextensive. 

  Under the contract claim the injured party can recover actual damages for the direct and natural consequences of the breach, or for damages that were within
the contemplation of the contracting parties. The damages recoverable for intentional interference are not measured by contract rules. The injured party can recover from the tortfeasor: the pecuniary loss of the benefits of the contract; consequential losses for which the interference is the legal cause; and, emotional distress or actual harm to reputation if they are reasonably to be expected to result from the interference. Thus, the actual damages under the contract claim and tort claim will be coextensive only with respect to the lost benefits of the contract which were a direct and natural consequence of the breach, or within the contemplation of the contracting parties.
[The injured party] cannot collect double recovery (once from each defendant) for actual damages which are coextensive under the contract and tort claims. 

Id. at 147-48, 503 S.E.2d at 482 (quoting Ross v. Holton, 640 S.W.2d 166 (Mo. Ct. App. 1982) (internal citations omitted)) (emphasis added).
In the present case, Collins was awarded actual damages for the breach-of-contract claim in the amount of $232,628.00,[10] plus $66,255.00 in pre-judgment interest.Â  Collins was also awarded $157,449.66[11] in actual damages for the tortious-interference claim, plus $1,569,013.00 in punitive damages.Â  
In my view, Collins should not have received two separate actual damages awards for a single breach of contract.Â  By awarding damages under both the breach-of-contract and tortious-interference claims, the trial court improperly awarded Collins the lost benefits of the contract twice.Â  Because the evidence regarding damages was the direct and natural consequence of a single breach, Collins was not entitled to the full amount of actual damages under both causes of action.
While I disagree that the lost volume seller doctrine is applicable in a tort case, I would urge that if the doctrine is to be adopted that the doctrine be applied correctly.Â  
Generally, the lost volume seller doctrine allows for the recovery of the lost profits resulting from the breach by showing that the party would have been able to enter into the beached contract and a subsequent contract even if there was no breach.Â  Unique Designs, Inc. v. Pittard Machinery Co., 200 Ga.App. 647, 649, 409 S.E.2d 241, 243 (Ga. Ct. App. 1991).Â  However, the majorityâ€™s application of the doctrine allows for the double recovery from the same breach.Â  In essence, the application of the doctrine by the majority allows for the recovery of one set of damages for the breach-of-contract and second recovery in tort for the tortious-interference with contract claim resulting from the same breach but brought about by joint actors.Â  
As outlined above, in the present case, Collins settled its claim for breach of contract against Coats.Â  In addition, Collins sought damages against American Bingo for tortious interference of contract.Â  As a result, any recovery from American Bingo would have to be set off against any recovery from Coats.Â  See Restatement 2d Torts Â§ 774(2) (stating that payments made by the third person in settlement of the claim must be credited against the liability for causing the breach and go to reducing the damages for the tort).Â  Accordingly, I write to prevent a third recovery on the part of Collins.
In addition, I disagree with the concurrence that the issue of double recovery is not before the Court.Â  In my opinion, the issue arrives before this Court within the issue of when and how the lost volume seller doctrine is applied. Â As a result, I believe the Court should hold that the any recovery from American Bingo represents a double recovery and this amount should be offset from the Coatsâ€™ settlement. 
Therefore, in my view, the court of appeals erred in using the lost volume seller doctrine to affirm the damages award.Â  Moreover, in my view, the trial courtâ€™s calculation of damages was incorrect.Â  Consequently, I would reverse and remand this case for a re-calculation of damages.[12] Â 
BURNETT, J., concurs.

[1]Â  The parlors were owned by Coats and Coats Rental Amusements, and the Coatsâ€™ son, Wayne Coats.Â  The Coats were named in the complaint, but are not parties to this appeal. 
[2]Â  The master dismissed the civil conspiracy claim, and found for American on the unfair trade practices claim.Â  
[3] Â The term â€œlost volume sellerâ€ was coined by Professor Robert J. Harris in his article A Radical Restatement of the Law of Seller's Damages: Sales Act and Commercial Code Results Compared, 18 Stan.L.Rev. 66 (1965).Â  As noted by the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals in Famous Knitwear Corp. v. Drugfair Inc., 493 F2d 251 (4th Cir. 1974):
Assume a contract for the sale of a washing machine with a list price of $500. Buyer breaches, and seller resells that washing machine at the same list price that buyer had been willing to pay. However, the resale buyer is one of seller's regular customers who had intended to purchase a washing machine from him anyway. If the seller's total cost per machine was $300, he stood to gain an aggregate profit of $400, that is, $200 profit from each of two sales. Clearly the [UCC] 2-708 contract-market differential formula is inadequate in this situation since it gives no damages to the seller who has lost a $200 profit because of the breach.Â  In such a case the damage award should be the lost profit, that is, $200, for this will place the seller in as good a position as performance would have done.
Famous Knitwear, 493 F.2d at 254, n. 5 citing J. White & R. Summers, Handbook of the Law Under the Uniform Commercial Code, 7-9, at 226-27 (1972).Â  
[4]Â  It appears Pennsylvania is the only jurisdiction which rejects the concept of the lost volume seller.Â  See Gianetti v. Norwalk Hosp., 779 A.2d 847 (Conn. 1997), revâ€™d in part on other grounds 833 A.2d 891 (2003).Â  
[5] Â As stated by one commentator, the â€œNortheastern court's concern over the potential idleness of the lost volume seller is completely unwarranted. . . . as a general rule, the nonbreaching party has a duty to mitigate its damages by entering into a similar contract. However, the important qualification to this rule is that if the subsequent contract would have been made regardless of the breach, then that contract is not taken into consideration to minimize the damages. This is exactly the rule articulated by the second Restatement of Contracts and which the Northeastern court chose to ignore.â€Â  Daniel Matthews, Should the Doctrine of Lost Volume Seller Be Retained: A Response to Professor Breen, 51 U. Miami L.Rev. 1195, 1214 (1997) (hereinafter Matthews article).
[6]Â  That section provides, in part, â€œ[i]f the measure of damages . . . is inadequate to put a lessor in as good a position as performance would have, the measure of damages is the present value of the profit, including reasonable overhead, the lessor would have made from full performance . . . together with any incidental damages . . .due allowance for costs reasonably incurred and due credit for payments or proceeds of distribution.
[7]Â  Other â€œtestsâ€ have been adopted.Â  For example, in Sunrich v. Pacific Foods of Oregon, 2004 WL 1124492 (D. Or. 2004), the District Court for the District of Oregon held that â€œ[a]s an alleged lost volume seller, Pacific therefore bears the burden of establishing that its production capacity was such that, if Sunrich had not breached the Packing Agreement, Pacific would have been able to meet Sunrich's requirements, as well as the needs of alternative buyers.â€Â  See also Van Ness Motors v. Vikram, 535 A.2d 510, 511 (N. J. Super. 1987) (recognizing that â€œ[m]ost other jurisdictions have held that to qualify as a â€˜lost volumeâ€™ seller under Section 2-708(2), the seller needs to show only that it could have supplied both the breaching purchaser and the resale purchaser); Iran v. Boeing Co., 771 F.2d 1279 (9th Cir. 1985); Teradyne, Inc. v. Teledyne Industries, 676 F.2d 865, 868 (1st Cir.1982); Autonumerics, Inc. v. Bayer Industries, 696 P.2d 1330, 1340-41 (Ariz. App.1984); National Controls, Inc. v. Commodore Business Machines, Inc., 163 Cal.App.3d 688, 696-98, 209 Cal.Rptr. 636, 641-43 (1985).Â  An even more lenient test, as set forth by the Georgia Court of Appeals, requires that â€œ[the seller] must prove that even though he later resold the repudiated contract goods, the sale to the third party would have been made regardless of the buyer's breach so that the seller would have realized two profits from two sales. The key inquiry is the sellersâ€™ ability to provide the product to both the breaching buyer and the resale buyer.Â  Unique Designs, Inc. v. Pittard Machinery Co., 409 S.E.2d 241, 243 (Ga. 1991) (emphasis supplied).
[8] Â Â The dissent contends adoption of the lost volume seller doctrine is inappropriate, claiming the doctrine does not apply to tort claims.Â Â  However, American never argued below that the doctrine did not apply to Collinsâ€™ claim for tortious interference with contract.Â  Although American argued, generally, against adoption of the lost volume seller doctrine, it did not raise the argument now advanced by the dissent.Â  Accordingly, in my opinion the dissent errs in raising and addressing this issue sua sponte.Â  See State v. Cutro, 332 S.C. 100, 107, 504 S.E.2d 324, 327 (1998) (Toal dissenting) (issue which is procedurally barred should not be raised sua sponte by this Court); Rule 226(d)(2), SCACR (issue must have been raised in initial arguments to Court of Appeals).Â Â  See also Â Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review).Â  
Moreover, as noted by Justice Pleiconesâ€™ concurrence, the only issue on certiorari is whether or not to adopt the lost-volume seller doctrine, and whether it applies in this case.Â  The issue of double recovery as addressed in Justice Toalâ€™s dissent is not before this Court.
[9] This cause of action is also referred to as â€œintentional interference with contract.â€Â  Todd v. S.C. Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co., 287 S.C. 190, 192, 336 S.E.2d 472, 473 (1985).
[10] This award was calculated based on the terms of the contract signed by Collins and the other defendants, Coats and Coats Rental Amusements and Wayne Coats.Â  The contract provides that in the event of a breach, Collins shall be â€œentitled to liquidated damages in an amount equal to Collinsâ€™ average weekly share of the contents of the coin boxes, prior to said breach, multiplied by the number of weeks remaining in the unexpired term of this agreement.â€Â  
[11] Like the award for breach of contract, the award for tortious interference was calculated by taking Collinsâ€™ average revenue experience prior to the breach, multiplied by the number of weeks remaining in the contract.Â  The difference in this award, though, is that license fees and other operating expenses were deducted from the final amount.
[12] On remand, the court should also reconsider the award of punitive damages.Â  See McGee v. Bruce Hosp. Sys., 344 S.C. 466, 545 S.E.2d 286 (2001) (there must be an award of actual or nominal damages for a verdict of punitive damages to be supported).

title: State v. McCombs
description: This case involves the issue of whether the trial court erred by failing to grant a directed verdict in appellant's favor on the charge of intimidation of a court official.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
John L. McCombs, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dorchester County
Â James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26137
Heard March 8, 2006 - Filed April 17, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Deputy Chief Attorney Wanda H. Carter, of Â Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor David Michael Pascoe, Jr., of St. Matthews, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE MOORE:Â  Appellant was found guilty for intimidation of a court official and was sentenced to seven years in prison.Â  He argues the trial court erred by failing to grant a directed verdict in his favor. Â We certified this case from the Court of Appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, and now affirm.
FACTS
Donna Sands was appointed to represent appellant in a post-conviction relief (PCR) action.Â  After appellant received an unfavorable ruling from Judge Diane Goodstein in the case, he wrote Sands three letters.Â  Sands gave the third letter she received to Judge Goodstein because appellant wished to terminate her representation and because she was concerned about an alleged threat to her and Judge Goodstein contained in the letter.Â  Sands filed a motion for reconsideration on appellantâ€™s behalf after receiving the letter, but she was ultimately relieved from representing him.
Appellantâ€™s third letter stated, in pertinent part:

Dear Donna,
. . . I am most highly displeased over your lack of loyalty & professionality in handling my case.Â  . . . I must hereby terminate you from my case . . .
Do not do anything else, since you donâ€™t know how to force a ruling out of that incipant [sic] judge, who made that personally biased comment from the bench, when she stated that she had no intention of ordering my release.Â  I will not stop until I put you & her out of practice, since you personally acquise [sic] with her actions.Â  Send me that file.Â  . . .

Judge Goodstein testified that, after receiving the letter from Sands, she asked the solicitorâ€™s office to investigate the alleged threat.Â  Following the investigation, Judge Goodstein was shown the other two letters written by appellant[1] and she learned appellant was scheduled to be released from prison in approximately two years.Â  She testified she already knew that appellant had been convicted of a violent crime.Â  She believed appellant intended to threaten the court and interfere with the courtâ€™s process.Â  Although appellant did not directly contact her, Judge Goodstein stated she personally felt threatened and intimidated by him given his history.[2]Â  Further, she said she was frightened by the three letters, which she found to be â€œabsolutely vicious,â€ appellantâ€™s release date, and his statement to a SLED officer.Â  She interpreted appellantâ€™s statement in the letter that he would â€œput . . . her out of practiceâ€ as a threat to her personally and not to her law license.Â  Judge Goodstein testified that when she subsequently received the motion to reconsider in appellantâ€™s PCR case, she recused herself because she could not be fair and impartial given that appellant had injected her personally into the case.
As part of the investigation into the alleged threat, SLED Officer John Garrison interviewed appellant while he was incarcerated.Â  When Garrison asked appellant if, when he got out, he intended to go see Sands and Judge Goodstein, appellant replied, â€œI donâ€™t know, I think Iâ€™ll have to go see them.â€Â  Garrison testified appellant made no other statement during the interview that was threatening other than that he was going to see Judge Goodstein when he was released.Â  Garrison stated his opinion was that a threat had been made against Judge Goodstein.
Following the close of the Stateâ€™s evidence, appellantâ€™s directed verdict motion was denied.Â  The jury returned a verdict of guilty and appellant moved for a new trial.Â  The court denied the motion because there was evidence to support the juryâ€™s verdict.
ISSUE

Did the trial court err by failing to grant a directed verdict in appellantâ€™s favor?

DISCUSSION
Appellant argues the trial court erred by failing to grant a directed verdict in his favor where there was insufficient evidence of his guilt.[3]
A defendant is entitled to a directed verdict when the State fails to produce evidence of the offense charged.Â  State v. McHoney, 344 S.C. 85, 544 S.E.2d 30 (2001).Â  If there is any direct evidence or substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, we must find the case was properly submitted to the jury.Â  State v. Buckmon, 347 S.C. 316, 555 S.E.2d 402 (2001).Â  On appeal from the denial of a directed verdict, we must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the State.Â  State v. McHoney, supra.
Appellant was charged with intimidation of a court official pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-9-340 (2003).Â  Section 16-9-340 states:

(A)   It is unlawful for a person by threat or force to:
  
(1)   intimidate or impede a judge . . . in the discharge of his duty as such; or
(2)   destroy, impede, or attempt to obstruct or impede the administration of justice in any court.
  

The trial court did not err by denying the motion for a directed verdict.Â  There was evidence reasonably tending to prove appellantâ€™s guilt of the stated crime.Â  The statements in the letters combined with appellantâ€™s violent history, his impending release date, and his statement to Officer Garrison that he was going to see Judge Goodstein after he was released, qualified as a threat and an attempt to interfere with the courtâ€™s process.Â  Judge Goodsteinâ€™s ability to discharge her duty as a judge was impeded when she had to recuse herself from appellantâ€™s case.
CONCLUSION
Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the State and because there is evidence sufficient to survive a directed verdict motion, the trial court appropriately submitted this case to the jury.Â  Therefore, the decision of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
 TOAL, C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice J. Mark Hayes, II, concur.

[1]The first letter appellant wrote to Sands contained the following statements:Â  â€œI hope to see you in Hell, because you are not going to like what I have to do just for you.Â  . . . There is a price for everything, and you will find it particularly bitter.â€
The second letter contained the following statements:

. . . I have a plan for you.Â  I hope that you enjoyed that $500 you got for selling me out, because you will regret what you have done, and I will guarantee it.Â  . . . How valuable is your practice to you?Â  . . . If you think that you can do anything to a walking dead man, hit me with your best shot, because I will handle you . . . .Â  I am set to destroying you, just like pulling the wings off of a fly, do you understand this?Â  For whom does the bell toll?Â  . . . By your own incompetent hand are you destroyed, when you reap as you have sown.Â  Do you think that I will at all spare your images?

[2]Appellant was incarcerated in approximately 1981 for criminal sexual conduct and assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature.
[3]The State argues the issue is not preserved for review because appellant did not renew his motion for a directed verdict at the close of all the evidence.Â  However, because appellant did not present any evidence, he was not required to renew that motion.Â  Cf. State v. Bailey, Op. No. 4079 (S.C. Ct. App. filed January 23, 2006) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 4 at 91, 95, n.4) (if defendant presents evidence after denial of his directed verdict motion at the close of the Stateâ€™s case, he must make another directed verdict motion at the close of all evidence in order to appeal the sufficiency of the evidence).

title: Thomas v. McGriff
description: The family court held that it lacked subject-matter jurisdiction over Appellant's action to declare that Appellant was the common-law spouse of a deceased woman on the date of the woman's death.  The Court reversed.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Floyd Thomas, Jr., Appellant,
v.
Pearlie Mae McGriff, as Personal Representative
of the Estate of Ella Mae McGriff, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lancaster County
Â Brooks P. Goldsmith, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 26138
Heard March 8, 2006 - Filed April 17, 2006

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Robin Page Freeland and Francis L. Bell, Jr., both of Bell, Tindal & Freeland, of Lancaster, for Appellant.
B. Michael Brackett, of Moses, Koon & Brackett, of Columbia, and David R. Blackwell, of Lancaster, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE PLEICONES: Â Appellant Floyd Thomas, Jr. (Appellant) brought this action in the family court against Respondent Pearlie Mae McGriff (Respondent), as Personal Representative of the Estate of Ella Mae McGriff, for a declaration that Appellant and Ella Mae McGriff were common-law spouses on the date of Ella Maeâ€™s death.Â  The family court granted Respondentâ€™s motion to dismiss for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction, holding that because Ella Mae was deceased and her probate estate was open, the probate court had exclusive jurisdiction over the matter.Â  We certified the case pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, and we now reverse the family courtâ€™s decision and remand the case to the family court for further proceedings.
ISSUE

Whether the family court erred in dismissing Appellantâ€™s action for
lack of subject-matter jurisdiction.

ANALYSIS
As the family court noted, this case turns on the interpretation of two statutes: South Carolina Code sections 20-7-420(5)[1] and 62-1-302(a)(1).[2]Â  Section 20-7-420(5) provides:Â  â€œThe family court shall have exclusive jurisdiction ... [t]o hear and determine actions to determine the validity of marriages.â€ Â Section 62-1-302(a)(1) provides:Â  â€œTo the full extent permitted by the Constitution, and except as otherwise specifically provided, the probate court has exclusive original jurisdiction over all subject matter related to ... estates of decedents, including the contest of wills, construction of wills, and determination of heirs and successors of decedents and estates of protected persons.â€[3]
The family court ruled that section 20-7-420(5) does not apply when one of the parties to the purported common-law marriage is deceased.Â  Rather, the court held, section 62-1-302(a)(1) applies, because a determination that a party was the common-law spouse of the decedent is really a determination that the party is an heir of the decedent.Â  We disagree.Â  
Reading the statutes together, jurisdiction to determine the existence of a common-law marriage depends upon the ultimate issue before the court.Â  If the ultimate issue is heirship, which is within the probate courtâ€™s exclusive jurisdiction, then the probate court has jurisdiction to resolve the threshold issue whether the decedent was a party to a common-law marriage.Â  If the existence of a common-law marriage is itself the ultimate issue, then the family court has exclusive jurisdiction. Â Cf. Neely v. Thomasson, 365 S.C. 345, 350-51, 618 S.E.2d 884, 887-88 (2005) (recognizing the difference between jurisdiction over an action and jurisdiction over an issue, and holding that although section 20-7-420(7)[4] vests the family court with exclusive jurisdiction over actions to determine paternity, under section 62-1-302(a)(1) the probate court has jurisdiction to resolve the issue of paternity when the issue is essential to the probate courtâ€™s determination of heirs). 
Here, Appellant brought an action for a declaration that he and Ella Mae McGriff were in a common-law marriage on the date of Ella Maeâ€™s death.Â  Appellant admits that he might seek to utilize the declaration, if the family court makes it, to claim in the probate court that he is an heir of Ella Mae.Â  While it would have been more judicially economical for Appellant to claim heirship in the probate court and allow the probate court to resolve the common-law-marriage issue, nothing prohibited Appellant from first bringing this action in the family court.Â  The family court therefore erred in dismissing the action for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction.Â  
CONCLUSION
The family court has exclusive subject-matter jurisdiction to determine an action for a declaration that a common-law marriage exists or existed.Â  The probate court has exclusive subject-matter jurisdiction to determine heirs, which might involve the issue whether a common-law marriage existed.Â  Whether the family court or probate court has jurisdiction over the issue of common-law marriage depends on the nature of the action in which the issue arises.Â  Here, Appellantâ€™s action is for a declaration that he and Ella Mae McGriff were parties to a common-law marriage on the date of Ella Maeâ€™s death.Â  Appellant does not now seek a determination that he is an heir of Ella Maeâ€™s estate.Â  Consequently, the family court has exclusive subject-matter jurisdiction over Appellantâ€™s action.Â  We therefore reverse the dismissal of the action and remand the case to the family court for further proceedings.Â  
 REVERSED AND REMANDED.  
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, JJ., and Acting Justice J. Mark Hayes, II, concur.

[1]Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(5) (1976) (re-designated by 2005 Act No. 132, Â§Â§ 1-3; see S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(A)(5) (Supp. 2005)).
[2]Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-302(a)(1) (Supp. 2005).
[3]Â  The General Assembly amended both statutes, effective June 3, 2005.Â  See 2005 Act No. 132, Â§Â§ 1-4.Â  Each statute now specifically provides that the family and probate courts have subject-matter jurisdiction over issues relating to common-law marriage, except that the probate court has jurisdiction only to the extent that the issues are connected to estate, guardianship, or conservatorship matters.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 20-7-420(B) and 62-1-302(c) (Supp. 2005).
[4]Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(7) (1976) (re-designated by 2005 Act No. 132, Â§Â§ 1-3; see S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(A)(7) (Supp. 2005)).

title: State v. Price
description: The Court affirmed Appellantâ€™s conviction for murder.  Appellant argued the trial court committed reversible error by admitting hearsay testimony.  The Court found the testimony was inadmissible hearsay but the improper admission of such testimony was harmless error.  Appellant also argued the testimony violated his right to confront witnesses against him as provided by the Sixth Amendment of the United States Constitution and Article 1, Â§ 14, of the South Carolina Constitution.  The Court found this issue was not preserved for review.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Jeroid John Price, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â Reginald I. Lloyd, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26139
Heard March 22, 2006 - Filed April 17, 2006 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Acting Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of South Carolina Office of Appellant Defense; and Amye L. Rushing, of Hammonds & Rushing, PA, both ofÂ  Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh,
Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General Jeffrey A. Jacobs, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Warren Blair Giese, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE BURNETT: Â Jeroid John Price (Appellant) was convicted of the murder of Carl Smalls and was sentenced to thirty-five years imprisonment.Â  Appellant appeals and this Court certified the case for review from the Court of Appeals, pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On December 6, 2002, Alpha Phi Alpha fraternity hosted a party at Club Voodoo in Columbia, South Carolina.Â  During the party, a confrontation between rival gangs, the Bloods and the Crips, occurred.Â  Appellant, who conceded he was affiliated with the Bloods, and Smalls, a member of the Crips, confronted each other. Â 
Around 2:00 a.m. on December 7, the party ended.Â  Ryan Brooks retrieved a semi-automatic pistol from his car to protect himself and
Appellant retrieved a pistol from his car for protection while his friends counted the money collected at the door that night.Â  Derrick Watson testified around 2:00 a.m. Smalls asked him for a gun, but Watson did not have one.Â  
Brooks saw Appellant and Smalls talking in the club.Â  He testified Appellant reached towards his own waist and Smalls rushed Appellant; the two men struggled over Appellantâ€™s pistol.Â  During the struggle, the pistol was pointed towards Brooks, who fired his own gun and shot Smalls.Â  After firing his weapon, Brooks ran out of the club and heard more gunshots.[1] Â 
Marcus Jones heard the first gunshot and saw the victim on the ground.Â  He then saw two more shots and described the gunfire as â€œcoming straight down.â€Â  Jones testified the victim did not appear to have a gun and the gunman did not appear to be in danger.Â  He later identified Appellant as the gunman.Â  
Investigator James Richardson was qualified as an expert in gangs and gang activity.Â  Richardson testified about the history of the Bloods and the Crips, gang activities in Columbia, gang clothing, and gang hand signals.Â  During direct examination, Richardson testified Appellant was a member of the Bloods and was a supreme or officer within the gang.Â  
The trial judge overruled defense counselâ€™s objection to the hearsay testimony that Appellant was an officer in the Bloods.Â  On cross-examination, Richardson conceded he did not know Appellant and that his testimony regarding Appellant was based on information from informants and not on his own personal knowledge.
The State presented the following evidence seized from Appellantâ€™s apartment as part of its theory that Appellant was a member of the Bloods:Â  photographs of men, including Appellant, making Blood hand signals and wearing Blood colors; a gang code book; red clothing and hats; bullet-proof vests; and a document containing a pledge of allegiance to the United Blood Nation.Â  
Appellant admitted shooting Smalls but asserted he acted in self-defense.Â  Appellant testified he was not a Blood, but he was affiliated with that gang.Â  He further testified Smalls was physically larger than him and, on the night of the shooting, Smalls attacked him without provocation.Â  He testified they struggled over his gun and during this struggle the gun discharged, wounding Smalls. 
The trial judge instructed the jury on murder and self-defense.Â  Appellant was found guilty of murder, and this appeal follows.
ISSUE

Did the trial judge err in admitting testimony from an expert
witness in the areas of gangs and gang activity that Appellant was an officer in a gang when the expert based his testimony on
statements from informants? 

STANDARD OF REVIEW
The decision to admit or exclude testimony from an expert witness rests within the trial courtâ€™s sound discretion.Â  Mizell v. Glover, 351 S.C. 392, 570 S.E.2d 176 (2002); State v. Caldwell, 283 S.C. 350, 322 S.E.2d 662 (1984).Â  The trial courtâ€™s decision to admit expert testimony will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Myers, 359
S.C. 40, 596 S.E.2d 488 (2004).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law or a factual conclusion that is without evidentiary support. Â State v. McDonald, 343 S.C. 319, 540 S.E.2d 464 (2000); Fields v. Regional Med. Ctr. Orangeburg, 363 S.C. 19, 609 S.E.2d 506 (2005).
LAW/ANALYSIS
A.Â  Hearsay
Appellant argues the trial court erred in admitting testimony from Investigator Richardson that Appellant was a supreme or an officer within the Bloods because the testimony was improper hearsay.Â  We agree.
The State contends the testimony was admissible under Rules 702 and 703, SCRE,[2] because, when the testimony is viewed in context, Richardson did not solely base his opinion on hearsay information.Â  This argument is without merit. Â Richardson did not testify to his expert opinion, but rather relayed information from informants.Â  
Hearsay is an out of court statement offered to prove the truth of the matter asserted therein.Â  Rule 801(c), SCRE; State v. Brown, 317 S.C. 55, 451 S.E.2d 888 (1994).Â  The rule against hearsay prohibits the admission of evidence of an out of court statement to prove the truth of the matter asserted unless an exception to the rule applies. Rule 802, SCRE; Simpkins v. State, 303 S.C. 364, 401 S.E.2d 142 (1991).
Although Richardson identified items seized from Appellantâ€™s apartment as related to the Bloods (e.g., photograph with Appellant throwing a gang sign, notebook with a reference to Bloods, code book referring to the Bloods, and red clothing which is significant to the Bloods), Richardson did not testify he relied on these items in forming an opinion that Appellant was a supreme or officer in the Bloods.Â  Furthermore, Richardson testified he solely based his testimony that Appellant was a supreme on statements from informants.Â  This testimony was hearsay and was not admissible under any exception to the hearsay rule.
Although the testimony was improperly admitted, Appellant has not demonstrated reversible error.Â  See State v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 573, 336 S.E.2d 150, 151 (1985) (improper admission of hearsay evidence is reversible error only when the admission causes prejudice).Â  Generally, appellate courts will not set aside convictions due to insubstantial errors not affecting the result.Â  State v. Sherard, 303 S.C. 172, 176, 399 S.E.2d 595, 597 (1991).Â  Thus, an insubstantial error not affecting the result of the trial is harmless where guilt has been conclusively proven by competent evidence such that no other rational conclusion can be reached.Â  State v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 5, 377 S.E.2d 581, 584 (1989); Arnold v. State, 309 S.C. 157, 172, 420 S.E.2d 834, 842 (1992). Â Where a review of the entire record establishes the error is harmless beyond a reasonable doubt, the conviction should not be reversed.Â  State v. Pickens, 320 S.C. 528, 531, 466 S.E.2d 364, 366 (1996).Â  
Defense counsel impeached Richardsonâ€™s improper testimony by eliciting that his testimony was solely based on information from informants.Â  Also, the inadmissible hearsay testimony was merely cumulative.Â  See State v. Haselden, 353 S.C. 190, 577 S.E.2d 445 (2003) (admission of improper evidence is harmless where the evidence is merely cumulative to other evidence.); State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 435 S.E.2d 859 (1993) (any error in admission of evidence cumulative to other unobjected-to evidence is harmless).Â  Brooks testified Appellant was a Blood.Â  Further, Lieutenant James Smith testified bullet-proof vests were seized from Appellantâ€™s apartment and Richardson properly testified officers within gangs may have bullet-proof vests.Â  After reviewing the entire record, we find the improper admission of hearsay testimony that Appellant was an officer in the Bloods was harmless.
B.Â  Confrontation Clause
Appellant also argues Richardsonâ€™s testimony violated his right to confront witnesses under the Sixth Amendment to the United States Constitution and Article 1, Â§ 14, of the South Carolina Constitution.Â  This issue is not preserved for appellate review because Appellant did not properly raise the issue in the trial court.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
CONCLUSION
The admission of Richardsonâ€™s testimony that Appellant was a supreme or officer within the Bloods was harmless error and we affirm Appellantâ€™s conviction.
 AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] Brooks was also charged with the murder of Smalls.Â  
[2] Rule 702, SCRE, states: 
If scientific, technical, or other specialized knowledge will assist the
trier of fact to understand the evidence or to determine a fact in issue, a witness qualified as an expert by knowledge, skill, experience, training,
or education, may testify thereto in the form of an opinion or otherwise.Â  
Rule 703, SCRE, provides: 
The facts or data in the particular case upon which an expert bases an
opinion or inference may be those perceived by or made known to the  expert at or before the hearing. If of a type reasonably relied upon by
experts in the particular field in forming opinions or inferences upon the subject, the facts or data need not be admissible in evidence.
