text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
In the Matter of Richard A. Blackmon, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 26140
Submitted March 28, 2006 - Filed April 24, 2006Â Â 

DEFINITE SUSPENSION


  
    
      
Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Charles N. Pearman, Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for the Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
Richard A. Blackmon, of Sumter, pro se.Â  
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent (Agreement) pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to the imposition of an admonition, public reprimand, or definite suspension from the practice of law for a period of up to sixty (60) days.Â  See Rule 7(b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  Â In addition, respondent agrees to pay any and all costs associated with ODCâ€™s inquiry into these matters.Â  We accept the Agreement and definitely suspend respondent from the practice of law in this state for a sixty (60) day period.Â  The facts, as set forth in the Agreement, are as follows.Â  
FACTS
I.
Complainant A hired respondent to file a bankruptcy petition on her behalf; all of her papers related to the bankruptcy were located in respondentâ€™s office.Â  Respondent also possessed important documents regarding Complainant Aâ€™s deceased parentsâ€™ estates, their wills, and the deed to their property.Â  Â Â 
Complainant A attempted to contact respondent on numerous occasions to obtain the documents relating to her parents and to her own bankruptcy petition.Â  Respondent did not communicate with Complainant A.Â  
Respondent acknowledges he was in possession of the estate papers and other documents.Â  He also acknowledges his secretary informed him several times of Complainant Aâ€™s attempts to contact him.Â  Respondent states he did not adequately communicate with Complainant A because she did not fully pay him to file her Chapter 7 bankruptcy petition.Â  
II.
Complainants B and C hired respondent to assume representation in a Chapter 13 bankruptcy which had already been filed by another attorney.Â  The complainants attempted to contact respondent on several occasions to learn the status of their case and to seek an explanation as to why the trustee might dismiss their petition.Â  Respondent asserts the new electronic filing rules and his antiquated software were the cause of part of the problems associated with the amended bankruptcy plan.Â  
Respondent states he has no record of Complainants B and C contacting him with the frequency that they claim.Â  He blames his answering machine for possibly not receiving some of their messages.Â Â  Nevertheless, respondent admits he did not adequately communicate the bankruptcy process and its obligations to Complainants B and C.Â  
III.
Complainant D hired respondent to represent her in a motor vehicle accident.Â  She attempted to contact respondent on numerous occasions to obtain a status report on her case.[1]
In his response to the Notice of Full Investigation, respondent essentially stated he was working on Complainant Dâ€™s case.Â  According to his records, she was still under the care of her treating physician and he asked her for updated medical bills and a wage statement.Â  Respondent did not adequately address his failure to communicate with Complainant D.Â  He now acknowledges he did not provide Complainant D with diligent representation and that he did not adequately communicate with her.Â  
IV.
Complainant E hired respondent to represent her minor children who were involved in a motor vehicle accident.Â  Complainant E attempted to contact respondent on many occasions to obtain the status of her childrenâ€™s case.Â  Respondent failed to communicate with respondent concerning the status of the case.Â  Complainant E resorted to personally contacting the insurance company to determine what was happening with her childrenâ€™s case.Â  
In his response to the Notice of Full Investigation, respondent indicated he had been working on the case but was unable to settle the matter since another individual injured in the accident was still being treated.Â  Respondent did not adequately address his failure to communicate with Complainant E.Â  
Respondent now acknowledges he did not diligently represent Complainant E.Â  He further acknowledges he did not adequately communicate with Complainant E.Â  
V.
Respondent represented Complainant F in a criminal matter.Â  While in the midst of a post-conviction relief action, Complainant F contacted respondent by mail on two occasions and asked for his file.
Respondent failed to surrender Complainant Fâ€™s file.Â  Respondent acknowledges he received one request from the complainant about the file and told him he would provide the file to his post-conviction relief attorney if requested by the attorney or that he would provide the file to Complainant F at the conclusion of the post-conviction relief action.Â  
In his response to the Notice of Full Investigation, respondent stated he â€œhad no objectionâ€ to sending the file to Complainant F as soon as he had an opportunity to copy the file.Â  Respondent acknowledges he failed to return Complainant Fâ€™s file in a timely fashion.Â  
VI.
In 2001, Complainants G and H retained respondent to file an action in magistrateâ€™s court.Â  The case was apparently dismissed in May 2003 without the complainantsâ€™ knowledge.Â  
Respondent claims he was not aware the case had been dismissed.[2]Â  Complainants G and H attempted to contact respondent on numerous occasions to obtain the status of the case, but respondent did not return their telephone calls or schedule an appointment to discuss the case.Â  Respondent now acknowledges he did not provide these complainants with competent or diligent representation and he did not adequately communicate with them concerning the status of their case.Â  
_______
Respondent acknowledges his extensive disciplinary history.Â  See In the Matter of Blackmon, 361 S.C. 641, 606 S.E.2d 777 (2004); In the Matter of Blackmon, 344 S.C. 83, 543 S.E.2d 559 (2001); In the Matte of Blackmon, 309 S.C. 400, 424 S.E.2d 472 (1992); In the Matter of Blackmon, 295 S.C. 333, 368 S.E.2d 465 (1988).Â  Â Â 
LAW
Respondent admits that, by his misconduct, he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation to client); Rule 1.3 (lawyer act with reasonable diligence and promptness in representing a client); Rule 1.4 (lawyer shall keep client reasonably informed about status of a matter); Rule 1.15 (lawyer shall promptly deliver to client any property client is entitled to receive); Rule 1.16 (upon termination of representation, lawyer shall surrender property to which client is entitled);
Rule 8.4(a) (lawyer shall not violate Rules of Professional Conduct); and Rule 8.4(e) (lawyer shall not engage in conduct that is prejudicial to administration of justice).
Â Finally, respondent admits his misconduct constitutes a violation of Rule 7, RLDE, of Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (lawyer shall not violate Rules of Professional Conduct or any other rules of this jurisdiction regarding professional conduct of lawyers).Â  Â 
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and definitely suspend respondent from the practice of law for a sixty (60) day period.Â  In addition, respondent shall pay any and all costs associated with ODCâ€™s inquiry into this matter, including the court reporterâ€™s fee of $60.00.Â  Within fifteen days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413,
SCACR.
 DEFINITE SUSPENSION.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES,
concur.

[1] Complainant D states she attempted to contact respondent on more than one hundred occasions.Â  
[2] Respondent states the case was dismissed due to lack of service of process which was usually handled by the magistrateâ€™s court.Â

description: In this PCR case, the Court discusses the jury instruction on a first degree burglary charge.
text:
Pinckney v. state


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Mikell A. Pinckney, Respondent,
v.
State of South Carolina,
Petitioner.
      
    
  


Appeal from Lexington County
Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge

ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Opinion No. 26141Â 
Submitted March 22, 2006 - Filed April 24, 2006 

REVERSED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Sabrina C. Todd, all of Columbia, for petitioner.
Deputy Chief Attorney Wanda H. Carter, of South Carolina Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE MOORE:Â  We granted the Stateâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari to review the grant of post-conviction relief (PCR) and now reverse.
FACTS
Respondent was convicted of first degree burglary after he broke into a home at night and barricaded himself in the bathroom.Â  When police officers arrived, respondent threatened to kill himself and the officers by spilling lamp oil and lighting it.Â  On appeal, respondentâ€™s conviction was affirmed.[1]Â  He then commenced this action for PCR.
The PCR judge granted relief on the ground trial counsel was ineffective for failing to request an additional charge emphasizing that the intent to commit a crime must exist at the time of entry, and limiting the juryâ€™s consideration of intent to whether there was intent to commit the crime set forth in the indictment.[2]Â  
ISSUE
Was counsel ineffective for failing to request an additional charge?
DISCUSSION
First degree burglary is defined in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-311 (2003):

(A) A person is guilty of burglary in the first degree if the person enters a dwelling without consent and with intent to commit a crime in the dwelling, and either:
(1) when, in effecting entry or while in the dwelling or in immediate flight, he or another participant in the crime:
  
(a) is armed with a deadly weapon or explosive;Â  or
  

. . .

  
(c) uses or threatens the use of a dangerous instrument;Â  or
  

. . .

(3) the entering or remaining occurs in the nighttime.

At trial, in addition to defining the aggravating circumstances regarding explosives, a dangerous instrument, or entry in the nighttime, the trial judge charged the following:

Iâ€™m going to read from you directly from the law.Â  It says a person is guilty of burglary in the first degree if the person enters a dwelling without consent and with intent to commit a crime therein and either - and there are three other alternatives, and if any of these alternatives are proven beyond a reasonable doubt, along with entering without consent and with intent to commit a crime then that would be burglary in the first degree.Â  Again, if you find that that has been proven beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  Those three alternatives are:Â  while entering or being in the dwelling or in leaving the dwelling he is armed with a deadly weapon or explosive.Â  The other is that while entering or being in the dwelling or leaving the dwelling he uses or threatens the use of a dangerous instrument.Â  And the third is that the entering or remaining occurred in the nighttime. . . .
Now again, burglary in the first degree must be proven beyond a reasonable doubt that the defendant entered the dwelling without consent.Â  It must be proven beyond a reasonable doubt that when he entered, when he entered that he had intent to commit a crime therein.

(emphasis added).
This charge adequately instructed the jury that the State must prove that the intent to commit a crime existed at the time of entry.[3]Â  Counsel was not ineffective for failing to request a more emphatic or specific charge since the charge adequately stated the elements of first degree burglary.Â  See State v. Hughey, 339 S.C. 439, 529 S.E.2d 721 (2000) (failure to provide specific jury instructions not error when the given instructions use proper test for determining the issues); State v. Austin, 299 S.C. 456, 385 S.E.2d 830 (1989) (if the trial judge refuses to give a specific charge, there is no error if the charge given sufficiently covers substance of the request).
Further, there is no requirement that the intent element is satisfied only by proving an intent to commit the specific crime that is charged in the indictment as an aggravating circumstance.Â  The only requirement is that there be intent to commit any crime at the time of entry.Â  Cf.
State v. Peterson, 336 S.C. 6, 518 S.E.2d 277 (Ct. App. 1999) (to constitute burglary it is not necessary that the intended crime be committed).Â  
In conclusion, the charge given was adequate and counsel was not ineffective for failing to request an additional charge.Â  See Cartrette v. State, 323 S.C. 15, 448 S.E.2d 53 (1994) (counsel not ineffective for failing to request additional charge covered by substance of charge given).Â  The grant of PCR is 
REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur

[1] On appeal, respondent argued he was entitled to a directed verdict of acquittal because there was no evidence he intended to commit a crime at the time he entered the dwelling.Â  The Court of Appeals agreed and reversed respondentâ€™s conviction.Â  On review of that decision, however, we found respondentâ€™s actions after he entered the house were some evidence of his intent to commit a crime.Â  State v. Pinckney, 339 S.C. 346, 529 S.E.2d 526 (2000).Â  After remand to the Court of Appeals for consideration of an alternative ground of appeal, respondentâ€™s conviction was affirmed in an unpublished opinion.
[2] The indictment alleges that respondent did willfully and unlawfully enter a dwelling without consent and with the intent to commit a crime therein and 

was armed with a deadly weapon or explosive while in the dwelling and/or used or threatened the use of a dangerous instrument while in the dwelling, and/or did enter or remain in the dwelling in the nighttime, to wit: [respondent] did pour kerosene on himself and the floor of the dwelling and threatened to light it and threatened to set responding officers on fire. . . .

[3] At the PCR hearing, counsel testified that in her opinion the charge given covered this element but â€œin retrospectâ€ she wished she had asked for a more specific charge.
